Gallery","conditions":{"post_types":["tc-media-gallery"]},"placements":{"leaderboard":"93484953"}},{"name":"Run of site \/ fallback","conditions":[],"placements":{"native":"93501877","mobile_native":"93501878","leaderboard":"93484975","leaderboard_amp":"963912137","rightrail":"93484976","rightrail_desktop_native":"963903172","rightrail_mobile_native":"963903173","mobile_300x250":"93484973","mobile_dynamic":"93484974","post_footer":"963908972","amp":"93523784","rightrail_desktop_native2":"963913332"}}]},"assetURI":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/themes\/techcrunch-2017","breaking":"","live_event":"0","feature_islands":{"homepage":[{"id":2200571,"date":"2021-09-09T15:09:39","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:09:39","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200571"},"modified":"2021-09-09T17:28:48","modified_gmt":"2021-09-10T00:28:48","slug":"the-2022-chevrolet-silverado-gets-a-tech-upgrade-hands-free-trailering-and-a-new-zr2-off-road-flagship","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/the-2022-chevrolet-silverado-gets-a-tech-upgrade-hands-free-trailering-and-a-new-zr2-off-road-flagship\/","title":{"rendered":"The 2022 Chevrolet Silverado gets a tech upgrade, hands-free trailering and a new ZR2 off-road flagship"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">GM unveiled Thursday the 2022 Chevrolet Silverado, a full-sized pickup truck that received a major technology upgrade, including its hands-free Super Cruise advanced driver assistance system and an infotainment system with embedded Google services, as well as an overhauled interior. A new flagship trim, the off-road ZR2 truck with a factory-installed suspension lift, has also joined the Silverado lineup.<\/p>\n<p>The Silverado refresh comes ahead of GM&#8217;s electric vehicle offensive, which will include Chevrolet and GMC pickup trucks. <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">GM aims to deliver<\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> 30 new electric vehicles to the global market by 2025 and to transition to all zero-emission vehicles by 2035. GM said the new Silverado trims will arrive at dealerships in spring 2022.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>The exterior of the Chevy Silverado also received a refresh, including new front fascia and daytime running lights that animate when the driver walks up or away from the vehicle.\u00a0But the real change can be found in the cabin \u2014 and the hardware and software guts \u2014 of the truck.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200623\" style=\"width: 1290px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200623\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2200623 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg\" alt=\" 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2\" width=\"1280\" height=\"853\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg 1280w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200623\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2 and new headlights. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> GM<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Chevy offers the Silverado in the LT, RST, LT Trail Boss, ZR2, LTZ and High Country trims, all of which come standard with a 2.7-liter turbocharged engine \u2014 now with 420 pound-feet of torque (up 20% over the previous model). The maximum tow rating on 2WD models is 9,600 pounds. GM also made changes to smooth out shifting and give drivers more power on demand.<\/p>\n<p>The automaker also improved its 3.0 L Duramax turbocharged diesel engine to enable a max tow rating of 13,300 pounds (2WD models). Two other powertrains, the 5.3-liter V8 and the 6.2-liter V8, are also offered.<\/p>\n<p>The interior cabin has been revamped to make it feel more spacious and includes a 13.4-inch touchscreen and a new 12.3-inch configurable digital instrument cluster standard. Owners will also be able to add a rear camera mirror and a head-up display.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200602\" style=\"width: 1290px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200602\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2200602 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg\" alt=\"Chevrolet Silverado\" width=\"1280\" height=\"853\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg 1280w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200602\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The first-ever 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2. <strong>Image Credits<\/strong>: GM<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Finally, the Silverado interior will be offered in new colors, seat designs and premium materials. For model trims with bucket seats, the new center console incorporates an electronic shift controller.<\/p>\n<p>Alexandre Scartezini, Chevrolet Truck&#8217;s lead interior designer, has described it as more\u00a0contemporary and refined &#8220;with a hint of Corvette influence in its design DNA.&#8221;<\/p>\n<h2>Everything Google<\/h2>\n<p>Moving in deeper inside the vehicle, aka the infotainment, users will find Google, or more specifically Android Automotive, at the heart of the operating system. This means that Google Assistant, Google Maps and Google Play are all integrated into the infotainment screen.<\/p>\n<p>Android Automotive OS shouldn&#8217;t be confused with Android Auto, which is a secondary interface that lies on top of an operating system. Android Auto is an app that runs on the user&#8217;s phone and wirelessly communicates with the vehicle&#8217;s infotainment system. Both Android Auto and its Apple CarPlay counterpart will be offered in the new Silverado. GM said the system also works with Amazon Alexa.<\/p>\n<p>Meanwhile, Android Automotive OS is modeled after its open source mobile operating system that runs on Linux. But instead of running smartphones and tablets, Google modified it so automakers could use it in their cars. Google has offered an open source version of this OS to automakers for some time. In recent years, automakers have worked with the tech company to natively build in an Android OS that is embedded with all the Google apps and services.<\/p>\n<h2>Hands-free driving<\/h2>\n<p>All of the Silverado trims come standard with six active safety features, including automatic emergency braking, lane-keeping assist and forward collision alerts, a warning if the vehicle leaves its lane, a following distance indicator, automatic high beams and front pedestrian braking.<\/p>\n<p>The big change is the addition of the automaker&#8217;s Super Cruise hands-free driver-assistance technology, which will be an available option on the High Country trim. Importantly, the system can be used even while trailering. Certain features of Super Cruise like automatic lane changing and lane change on demand will be restricted if the truck is towing.<\/p>\n<p>Super Cruise uses a combination of lidar map data, high-precision GPS, cameras and radar sensors, as well as a driver attention system, which monitors the person behind the wheel to ensure they&#8217;re paying attention. Unlike Tesla&#8217;s Autopilot driver assistance system, users of Super Cruise do not need to have their hands on the wheel. However, their eyes must remain directed straight ahead.<\/p>\n<p>While GM has steadily improved Super Cruise since its introduction in 2017, for years it was limited to its luxury Cadillac brand and restricted to certain divided highways. That began to change in 2019 when GM announced plans to expand it to more models and use cases. The system can be activated on more than 200,000 miles of roads in the United States and Canada.<\/p>\n<p>The Silverado will offer other trailer assistance features, including one that will alert drivers to vehicles in their blind spot.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>GM unveiled Thursday the 2022 Chevrolet Silverado, a full-sized pickup truck that received a major technology upgrade, including its hands-free Super Cruise advanced driver assistance system and an infotainment system with embedded Google services, as well as an overhauled interior. A new flagship trim, the off-road ZR2 truck with a factory-installed suspension lift, has also =81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200170,"date":"2021-09-09T10:00:38","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T17:00:38","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200170"},"modified":"2021-09-09T09:34:58","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:34:58","slug":"supabase-raises-30m-for-its-open-source-insta-backend","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/supabase-raises-30m-for-its-open-source-insta-backend\/","title":{"rendered":"Open source backend-as-a-service startup Supabase raises $30M"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/supabase.io\">Supabase<\/a>, the backend-as-a-service startup, announced this week that it raised a $30 million Series A.<\/p>\n<p>Supabase is often described as an open source alternative to Google&#8217;s Firebase &#8230; which is a pretty good way to put it for those who know what Firebase is. For those who don&#8217;t: Supabase is a collection of tools that helps developers build projects more quickly by automatically handling a whole lot of the behind-the-scenes work and wiring.<\/p>\n<p>Create a project, and Supabase will give you a Postgres database; an API for interacting with said database that automatically evolves (and documents itself!) as your database changes; a user authentication system that plays friendly with the popular login providers (Facebook, Twitter, Google, Apple, etc.); a storage system for handling things like image and video uploads; and a UI for overseeing and managing it all. It takes a bunch of work you&#8217;d need to do to build just about any modern app or service and waves it away with a couple of clicks.<\/p>\n<p>Supabase is free for hobby projects (or when you just want to tinker with it). Once you start needing bigger databases or data backups, the price scales starting at $25 per project per month. Alternatively, you can <a href=\"https:\/\/supabase.io\/docs\/guides\/self-hosting\">deploy it yourself<\/a>, though that&#8217;s a bit tougher and currently means losing the management UI.<\/p>\n<p>This Series A comes pretty quickly following the company&#8217;s last raise \u2014 a $6 million round announced <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/15\/supabase-raises-6m-for-its-open-source-firebase-alternative\/\">in December 2020<\/a>. I&#8217;m told this round was funded predominantly by Coatue, with some of it reserved for a few new key angel investors, including GitHub co-founder Tom Preston-Werner, PagerDuty co-founder Alex Solomon and Docker co-founder Solomon Hykes.<\/p>\n<p>Supabase co-founder Paul Copplestone tells me that the team is now made up of 24 people, distributed all over the world. &#8220;We were born remote,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>This reasoning is twofold: The company started growing just as the pandemic began to spread, and it&#8217;s largely hiring people who are already working on and contributing to the tools that make Supabase possible. Why make them move around the world when they&#8217;re already doing a good job?<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;We use, I think, six different tools,&#8221; Copplestone said. &#8220;And we employ lead maintainers of several of those tools. We employ open source contributors, anyone who&#8217;s contributing, no matter where they live.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Supabase was part of Y Combinator&#8217;s Summer 2020 class, the accelerator&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/20\/y-combinator-officially-shifts-its-next-accelerator-class-to-fully-remote-format\/\">first cohort to be entirely remote.<\/a> Meanwhile, YC classes are growing increasingly large; the S20 batch, for example, came in at over 200 companies. It can be hard to stand out in a group like that, but Supabase seemed to do it \u2014 I was hearing chatter about them early and often.<\/p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s what it looks like to fire up a Supabase backend:<\/p>\n<p><span class=\"embed-youtube embed breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"><iframe class=\"youtube-player\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/dBOSUER_5T4?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;fs=1&#038;hl=en-US&#038;autohide=2&#038;wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Supabase, the backend-as-a-service startup, announced this week that it raised a $30 million Series A. Supabase is often described as an open source alternative to Google&#8217;s Firebase &#8230; which is a pretty good way to put it for those who know what Firebase is. For those who don&#8217;t: Supabase is a collection of tools that ],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2198898,"date":"2021-09-09T09:02:04","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:02:04","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2198898"},"modified":"2021-09-09T13:30:16","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T20:30:16","slug":"facebooks-first-smart-glasses-make-the-case-for-face-worn-wearables","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/facebooks-first-smart-glasses-make-the-case-for-face-worn-wearables\/","title":{"rendered":"Review: Facebook&#8217;s Ray-Ban Stories make the case for smart glasses"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Facebook&#8217;s first pair<\/span> of smart glasses doesn&#8217;t feel like much of a Facebook product.<\/p>\n<p>You won&#8217;t find the Facebook logo emblazoned on them or even its name in small print by the serial code. They aren&#8217;t &#8220;Facebook Stories&#8221; or &#8220;Ray-Ban&#8217;s Facebook Stories&#8221; or even &#8220;Ray-Ban Stories in collaboration with Facebook<em>.&#8221; <\/em>Unlike other Facebook-designed hardware like the Quest 2 or Portal, the Ray-Ban Stories feel more self-aware and restrained as though the company knew exactly what use cases they needed to hit, and stopped themselves from trying to do much more than that.<\/p>\n<p>The glasses made in partnership with eyewear giant EssilorLuxottica are certainly the most basic device Facebook has shipped. They only do a few things: You can take photos and videos; you can take phone calls; and you can listen to music. That&#8217;s it. But bringing audio into the mix via near-ear speakers embedded in the arms of the frames makes these a much more realized device than Snap&#8217;s Spectacles that shipped five years ago.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200208\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200208\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2200208\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"372\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg 1747w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg?resize=150,55 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg?resize=300,109 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg?resize=768,279 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg?resize=680,247 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg?resize=1536,558 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/C41A3554-9A1E-4724-AC22-9D787ADB758A-3669-000001DFF409F3AF-2.jpg?resize=50,18 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200208\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Ray-Ban&#8217;s classic dumb Wayfarers (left) next to the smart Ray-Ban Stories Wayfarers (right). <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Lucas Matney<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Let&#8217;s dig a bit into what this device does and how it feels to use it in daily life.<\/p>\n<p>One thing to note about the $299 Ray-Ban Stories is that they can be worn pretty inconspicuously. People are probably more likely to notice the cameras than their slightly inflated dimensions. That&#8217;s already a revolutionary advance, which pushes these past the level of &#8220;toy,&#8221; which Spectacles never really seemed to eclipse. The Ray-Ban partnership was particularly savvy given the thicker-than-average frames on their standard Wayfarer design.<\/p>\n<p>What onlookers are more likely to notice is you tapping the frame of your glasses to control them. Pressing the button on the right arm will take a 30-second video, a long-press will snap a photo. You can also use the voice command, &#8220;Hey Facebook, take a video&#8221; and do the same for photos. (For the record, I&#8217;m not sure whether this is a sentence I&#8217;d feel great about hearing a stranger nearby me in public say.) A small LED light sparks up when the camera is capturing footage though it&#8217;s a pretty low-key indicator.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200158\" style=\"width: 1786px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200158\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-2200158 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1776\" height=\"1184\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg 1776w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2B4A4D9D-8F90-40EC-B139-0CBB50C06E85-3669-000001E063A272C1.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1776px) 100vw, 1776px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200158\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Lucas Matney<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The photo and video quality of the glasses is pretty middling, but plenty of forgiveness can be levied given the size of the device. The twin 5 MP cameras can shoot 2592&#215;1944 pixel photos and 1184&#215;1184 pixel square format videos. The quality seems to be about on par with where smartphone cameras were about 10 years ago, so it&#8217;s clear there&#8217;s plenty of room for improvement. Post-processing on the phone during upload enhances the photos and hides some of their struggles with low lighting while making the photos pop a bit more with saturation.<\/p>\n<p>[gallery ids=\"2200191,2200215,2200217,2200213\"]<\/p>\n<p><img class=\"breakout alignnone size-full wp-image-2200191\" alt=\"\" \/><\/p>\n<p>The twin camera setup is used to add 3D effects to your photos, but at the moment the filters aren&#8217;t great and there&#8217;s honestly not much there. Hopefully, Facebook invests a bit more in the software over time but with fairly low-quality photos, I don&#8217;t completely see the reasoning in having two cameras to begin with.<\/p>\n<p>Also worth noting is that using the glasses requires linking them to a new Facebook app called View, which is basically a simple media viewer app that gets around limitations in how media from external devices can be uploaded to your phone. This is where you can also make quick edits to your photos and videos before dumping them to your photo roll or sharing them to Facebook or Instagram.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200163\" style=\"width: 1786px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200163\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-2200163 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1776\" height=\"1184\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg 1776w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/267B6F38-B65B-4C25-B86F-8B34707DB1A9-3669-000001E04DBF0928.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1776px) 100vw, 1776px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200163\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Lucas Matney<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Audio is probably the most interesting bit of these glasses. The near-ear speakers will surprise you with their quality in quiet spaces and leave you dissatisfied once you find yourself in a noisier environment. Unfortunately for Facebook, most outdoor spaces are a bit louder and sunglasses are mostly being used outdoors. The audio will work in a pinch outdoors for listening to tunes, but I honestly can&#8217;t see them replacing my AirPods anytime soon. The audio is much better suited for low-fidelity activities like phone calls, but I also had some issues with the three-microphone array picking up too much background noise while I was walking outdoors.<\/p>\n<p>Battery life is surprisingly solid, but they also have the benefit of a charging battery case, which is incidentally the best place to store them. The case is a little bulky but they also include a microfiber pouch to protect the lenses. Facebook says you can get six hours of straight audio and &#8220;all-day&#8221; usage otherwise.<\/p>\n<p>One of their weirder quirks is their lack of waterproofing or even splash-proofing, something that doesn&#8217;t seem like a great quality for a pair of sunglasses. It&#8217;s just one more thing indicating that while the thicker frame aesthetic of sunglasses makes more sense for a smart-glasses design, this product really thrives more indoors.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200162\" style=\"width: 1786px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200162\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-2200162 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1776\" height=\"1184\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg 1776w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/71C7AD72-4DAE-40E4-9F69-0E0D3523301E-3669-000001E06E9EC365.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1776px) 100vw, 1776px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200162\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Lucas Matney<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p>This isn&#8217;t Facebook&#8217;s first rodeo when it comes to hardware and you can see the company&#8217;s maturation.<\/p>\n<p>They aren&#8217;t an AR\/VR device, but you can also see generations of Oculus products in the Ray-Ban Stories&#8217; design. On-ear audio born from the Oculus Go, a touchpad interface reminiscent of the Gear VR, simple and restrained audio controls first launched on the Quest. The hardware is a distillation of features and lessons learned from selling VR to a generally indifferent public that has seemed to warm up to it a bit over the years.<\/p>\n<p>Meanwhile, you can also see years of Facebook screwing up its messaging and torching its brand name in the process, making itself the boogeyman of both political parties, courting enemies in the press and earning an outsized amount of distrust from the average internet user, something that probably led to these carrying so little Facebook branding. The Ray-Ban Stories will certainly have their detractors, but Facebook choosing to be conservative in their functionality and not toss in too many future-flung passive sensors will likely do them a favor. The Facebook View app is bare bones and Facebook details that photos and videos captured using the Stories won&#8217;t be used to serve ads. All that said, while we&#8217;ve certainly come a long way since the Google Glass debut in 2013, face-mounted cameras still feel icky when it comes to privacy in public and this device will undoubtedly reignite that conversation in a major way.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200160\" style=\"width: 1786px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200160\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-2200160 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1776\" height=\"1184\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg 1776w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/21C0EEBC-7243-4B85-830A-F9E39F911E1F-3669-000001E00F0122ED.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1776px) 100vw, 1776px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200160\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Lucas Matney<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Baggage aside, my broadest takeaway is that the Ray-Ban Stories feel like a very important product &#8212; one that actually sells the idea of face-worn wearables.<\/p>\n<p>The glasses are smartly designed and can be worn discreetly. That said, it&#8217;s clear Facebook made plenty of sacrifices to achieve such an aggressive form factor; the glasses honestly don&#8217;t do anything particularly well &#8212; photo and video quality is pretty lackluster, the in-frame speakers perform poorly outdoors and calls aren&#8217;t the most pleasant experience. For $299, that might make the first-generation a tough sell for some. But all that said, I think Facebook mostly made the right compromises for a product that they&#8217;ve repeatedly indicated is meant to be a stepping stone on the road toward an augmented reality future.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200165\" style=\"width: 1786px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200165\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-2200165 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1776\" height=\"671\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg 1776w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg?resize=150,57 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg?resize=300,113 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg?resize=768,290 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg?resize=680,257 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg?resize=1536,580 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/66362E4D-99DD-4F0E-9E8A-B324CBC74837-3669-000001E097340055.jpg?resize=50,19 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1776px) 100vw, 1776px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200165\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Facebook&#8217;s smart Ray-Ban Stories alongside my pair of classic Ray-Ban 2140 Wayfarers. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Lucas Matney<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"dkwj8lWMQd\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/facebook-debuts-its-ray-ban-stories-smart-sunglasses\/\">Facebook debuts its Ray-Ban Stories smart sunglasses<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Facebook debuts its Ray-Ban Stories smart \/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=24435"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=24435"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=24435"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":152255,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/sunglasses\/","name":"Sunglasses","slug":"sunglasses","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/152255"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=152255"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=152255"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=152255"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=152255"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2199964,"date":"2021-09-09T09:00:45","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:00:45","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2199964"},"modified":"2021-09-09T12:18:54","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T19:18:54","slug":"scout-ventures-fund-three","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/scout-ventures-fund-three\/","title":{"rendered":"With $55M third fund, Scout Ventures is funding veterans ready to tackle the hardest technical challenges"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">When it comes to people pushing the frontiers of science, few institutions can match the talent of the Department of Defense, the intelligence agencies and the U.S. national laboratory system. With ample budgets and flexible oversight under that aura of national security, ambitious scientists and engineers are working on everything from quantum computing to next-generation satellites.<\/p>\n<p>That wealth of talent is often left behind in the frenetic product development and fundraising world of Silicon Valley. Langley, Arlington and Los Alamos are a far cry from Palo Alto or New York City. Even more challenging is the career transition: the government is, well, the government, and the private sector is, well, the private sector. Moving from one to the next can be quite jarring.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.scoutventures.com\">Scout Ventures<\/a> wants to act as the bridge between the startup world and that vast science and technology workforce, with a particular focus on veterans of the military, intelligence agencies and national labs. Founded about a decade ago in 2012 by Brad Harrison, the firm raised two funds and invested in several dozen companies at the earliest stages, including identity verification platform <a href=\"http:\/\/ID.me\">ID.me<\/a> (<a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/alexkonrad\/2021\/03\/22\/idme-reaches-billion-valuation-for-identity-software-used-by-22-states\/\">now valued at $1.5 billion<\/a>), <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2017\/10\/18\/bespoke-post-series-a\/\">men\u2019s subscription service Bespoke Post<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/19\/leagueapps-raises-15m-to-be-the-operating-system-for-youth-sports-organizations\/\">youth sports management platform LeagueApps<\/a>. It also incubated companies like <a href=\"https:\/\/www.fiercehealthcare.com\/tech\/health-tech-startup-building-social-care-networks-and-it-just-reached-unicorn-status\">health services company Unite Us<\/a>.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ZUdm2cl9f5\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/19\/leagueapps-raises-15m-to-be-the-operating-system-for-youth-sports-organizations\/\">LeagueApps raises $15M to be the &#8216;operating system&#8217; for youth sports organizations<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;LeagueApps raises $15M to be the &#8216;operating system&#8217; for youth sports organizations&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/19\/leagueapps-raises-15m-to-be-the-operating-system-for-youth-sports-organizations\/embed\/#?secret=ZUdm2cl9f5\" data-secret=\"ZUdm2cl9f5\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>The firm announced this morning that is has raised a $55 million third fund, which will continue its focus on backing veterans while centering its investment thesis on frontier tech in areas like machine learning, robotics, drones, physical security, quantum computing and space (that said, the firm does not invest in weapons).<\/p>\n<p>Harrison, who has been a long-time angel investor prior to forming Scout Ventures and is a West Point grad and Army Airborne Ranger, said that when he started to look at the track records of the most successful founders he backed, many of them happened to be veterans. So he started doubling down on that thesis, eventually hiring Wes Blackwell who graduated from the Naval Academy and Sam Ellis in Brooklyn from West Point as his co-partners.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2199967\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2199967\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2199967\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"453\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg 2000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/HGC_0162-1.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2199967\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Scout Ventures partners Wes Blackwell, Brad Harrison and Sam Ellis. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Scout Ventures.<\/p><\/div><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Scout is a traditional seed stage fund, and Harrison said that the firm targets roughly a deal per month, with a typical check between $500,000 and $1 million targeting 10% ownership. The firm also reserves $2-3 million in capital for follow-on investments.<\/p>\n<p>One of the firm\u2019s unique differentiators is taking advantage of ample non-dilutive funding from government programs and locking that in for its portfolio companies. Harrison said that the firm typically can secure three dollars of such funds for each dollar it invests, allowing its portfolio companies to grow faster for longer and with less dilution. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing the most active money flowing through Air Force number one, Army number two, and then you are seeing some money flowing through the Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation,\u201d Harrison said.<\/p>\n<p>In terms of companies, the target is so-called dual-use startups that have applications that can be used by both the public and private sectors. These are \u201ccore, disruptive technologies that we believe are going to bring a shift change, so they inherently have applications to the DoD and the commercial sector,\u201d he said. \u201cThey are hard to find, and that is why we talk to so many companies.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>As examples of startups within this thesis, Harrison pointed to four companies in quantum computing and others in electronic warfare, where applications can be as important to the NSA as to telecoms like Verizon and T-Mobile. He also pointed out companies like De-Ice, which is using electromagnetic technology to make deicing of planes and other equipment faster and safer. Such technology could improve operations for the Air Force as well as civilian carriers.<\/p>\n<p>Ultimately, Scout hopes that its unique network and focus will allow it to access these \u201chard-to-reach\u201d founders who are \u201creally distrustful of most VCs,\u201d Harrison said. \u201cThat makes us competitive.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Among the LPs of the new fund are the New Mexico State Investment Council (home of the Los Alamos National Laboratory), former Citigroup chairman Richard Parsons, Auctus Investment Group, restaurateur and brewer David Kassling, and Michael Loeb.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>When it comes to people pushing the frontiers of science, few institutions can match the talent of the Department of Defense, the intelligence agencies and the U.S. national laboratory system. With ample budgets and flexible oversight under that aura of national security, ambitious scientists and engineers are working on everything from quantum computing to next-generation China&#8217;s new data privacy law means for US tech firms"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Scott W. Pink<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/omelvenymyers\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\t<a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/scott-pink\/\">Scott W. Pink<\/a> is special counsel in O\u2019Melveny\u2019s Data Security &amp; Privacy practice based in Silicon Valley. He advises technology, media, entertainment and a variety of companies on issues of cybersecurity and privacy, IP  counseling; social media law; and advertising, marketing, and promotions law. \t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">China enacted a sweeping<\/span> new data privacy law on August 20 that will dramatically impact how tech companies can operate in the country. Officially called the Personal Information Protection Law of the People\u2019s Republic of China (PIPL), the law is the first national data privacy statute passed in China.<\/p>\n<p>Modeled after the European Union\u2019s General Data Protection Regulation, the PIPL imposes protections and restrictions on data collection and transfer that companies both inside and outside of China will need to address. It is particularly focused on apps using personal information to target consumers or offer them different prices on products and services, and preventing the transfer of personal information to other countries with fewer protections for security.<\/p>\n<p>The PIPL, slated to take effect on November 1, 2021, does not give companies a lot of time to prepare. Those that already follow GDPR practices, particularly if they&#8217;ve implemented it globally, will have an easier time complying with China&#8217;s new requirements. But firms that have not implemented GDPR practices will need to consider adopting a similar approach. In addition, U.S. companies will need to consider the new restrictions on the transfer of personal information from China to the U.S.<\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--right\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tImplementation and compliance with the PIPL is a much more significant task for companies that have not implemented GDPR principles.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s a deep dive into the PIPL and what it means for tech firms:<\/p>\n<h2>New data handling requirements<strong><br \/>\n<\/strong><\/h2>\n<p>The PIPL introduces perhaps the most stringent set of requirements and protections for data privacy in the world (this includes special requirements relating to processing personal information by governmental agencies that will not be addressed here). The law broadly relates to all kinds of information, recorded by electronic or other means, related to identified or identifiable natural persons, but excludes anonymized information.<\/p>\n<p>The following are some of the key new requirements for handling people&#8217;s personal information in China that will affect tech businesses:<\/p>\n<h3>Extra-territorial application of the China law<\/h3>\n<p>Historically, China regulations have only been applied to activities inside the country. The PIPL is similar in applying the law to personal information handling activities within Chinese borders. However, similar to GDPR, it also expands its application to the handling of personal information outside China if the following conditions are met:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li>Where the purpose is to provide products or services to people inside China.<\/li>\n<li>Where analyzing or assessing activities of people inside China.<\/li>\n<li>Other circumstances provided in laws or administrative regulations.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>For example, if you are a U.S.-based company selling products to consumers in China, you may be subject to the China data privacy law even if you do not have a facility or operations there.<\/p>\n<h3>Data handling principles<\/h3>\n<p>The PIPL introduces principles of transparency, purpose and data minimization: Companies can only collect personal information for a clear, reasonable and disclosed purpose, and to the smallest scope for realizing the purpose, and retain the data only for the period necessary to fulfill that purpose. Any information handler is also required to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the data it handles to avoid any negative impact on personal rights and interests.<\/p>\n<p><div collection and transfer that companies both inside and outside of China will need to Cribs","url":"\/shows\/tc-cribs","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605180,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2200666,"date":"2021-09-09T16:51:25","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T23:51:25","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200666"},"modified":"2021-09-09T19:32:24","modified_gmt":"2021-09-10T02:32:24","slug":"snyk-snags-another-530m-as-valuation-rises-to-8-4b","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/snyk-snags-another-530m-as-valuation-rises-to-8-4b\/","title":{"rendered":"Snyk snags another $530M as valuation rises to $8.5B"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"http:\/\/snyk.io\">Snyk<\/a>, the Boston-based late-stage startup that is trying to help developers deliver more secure code, announced another mega-round today. This one was for $530 million on an $8.5 billion valuation, with $300 million in new money and $230 million in secondary funding, the latter of which is to help employees and early investors cash in some of their stock options. The $8.5 billion valuation was up from $4.7 billion in March when <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/10\/snyk-raises-300-million-at-a-4-7-billion-valuation-as-employees-cash-in-and-the-security-company-beefs-up\/\">the company raised $300 million<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>The long list of investors includes an interesting mix of public investors, VC firms and strategics. Sands Capital Ventures and Tiger Global led the round, with participation from new investors Baillie Gifford, Koch Industries, Lone Pine Capital, T. Rowe Price and Whale Rock Capital Management. Existing investors also came along for the ride, including Accel, Addition, Alkeon, Atlassian Ventures, BlackRock, Boldstart Ventures, Canaan Partners, Coatue, Franklin Templeton, Geodesic Capital, Salesforce Ventures and Temasek.<\/p>\n<p>This round brings the total raised in funding to $775 million, excluding secondary rounds, according to the company. With secondary rounds, it&#8217;s up to $1.3 billion, according to Crunchbase <a href=\"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/organization\/snyk\">data<\/a>. The company has been raising funds at a rapid clip (note that the last three rounds include the Snyk money plus secondary rounds):<\/p>\n<p><img loading=\"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-2200722\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Screen-Shot-2021-09-09-at-10.25.31-PM.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"Snyk's last four rounds\" width=\"680\" height=\"176\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Screen-Shot-2021-09-09-at-10.25.31-PM.jpg 1250w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Screen-Shot-2021-09-09-at-10.25.31-PM.jpg?resize=150,39 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Screen-Shot-2021-09-09-at-10.25.31-PM.jpg?resize=300,78 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Screen-Shot-2021-09-09-at-10.25.31-PM.jpg?resize=768,199 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Screen-Shot-2021-09-09-at-10.25.31-PM.jpg?resize=680,176 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Screen-Shot-2021-09-09-at-10.25.31-PM.jpg?resize=50,13 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/p>\n<p>While the company wouldn&#8217;t share specific revenue figures, it did say that ARR has grown 158% YoY; given the confidence of this list of investors and the valuation, it would suggest the company is making decent money.<\/p>\n<p>Snyk CEO Peter McKay says that the additional money gives him flexibility to make some acquisitions if the right opportunity comes along, what companies often refer to as &#8220;inorganic&#8221; growth. &#8220;We do believe that a portion of this money will be for inorganic expansion. We&#8217;ve made three acquisitions at this point and all three have been very, very successful for us. So it&#8217;s definitely a muscle that we&#8217;ve been developing,&#8221; McKay told me.<\/p>\n<p>The company started this year with 400 people and McKay says they expect to double that number by the end of this year. He says that when it comes to diversity, the work is never really done, but it&#8217;s something he is working hard at.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;We&#8217;ve been able to build a lot of good programs around the world to increase that diversity and our culture has always been inclusive by nature because we&#8217;re highly distributed.&#8221; He added, &#8220;I&#8217;m not by any means saying we&#8217;re even remotely close to where we want to be. So I want to make that clear. There&#8217;s a lot we still have to do,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>McKay says that today&#8217;s investment gives him added flexibility to decide when to take the company public because whenever that happens it won&#8217;t have to be because they need another fundraising event. &#8220;This raise has allowed us to set up with strong, highly reputable public investors, and it gives us the financial resources to pick the timing. We are in control of when we do it and we will do it when it&#8217;s right,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"MYABJuVd5I\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/10\/snyk-raises-300-million-at-a-4-7-billion-valuation-as-employees-cash-in-and-the-security-company-beefs-up\/\">Snyk raises $300 million at a $4.7 billion valuation as employees cash in and the security company beefs up<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Snyk raises $300 million at a $4.7 billion valuation as employees cash in and the security company beefs up&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/10\/snyk-raises-300-million-at-a-4-7-billion-valuation-as-employees-cash-in-and-the-security-company-beefs-up\/embed\/#?secret=MYABJuVd5I\" data-secret=\"MYABJuVd5I\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Snyk, the Boston-based late-stage startup that is trying to help developers deliver more secure code, announced another mega-round today. This one was for $530 million on an $8.5 billion valuation, with $300 million in new money and $230 million in secondary funding, the latter of which is to help employees and early investors cash in has reportedly appointed wearable chief Kevin Lynch to lead its car division"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Apple has reportedly appointed a new executive to lead the development of its secretive self-driving car division. According to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2021-09-09\/apple-s-watch-software-chief-takes-over-self-driving-car-project?sref=10lNAhZ9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-ylk=\"elm:context_link;itc:0\" data-rapid_p=\"14\" data-v9y=\"1\"><em>Bloomberg<\/em><\/a>, the company has tapped Kevin Lynch to oversee Project Titan following the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/ford-hires-doug-field-204511159.html\" data-ylk=\"elm:context_link;itc:0\" data-rapid_p=\"15\" data-v9y=\"1\"><ins>departure of executive Doug Field<\/ins><\/a>, who left the iPhone maker for Ford earlier this week.<\/p>\n<p>The name may not be familiar, but if you\u2019ve watched any Apple event in recent years, you\u2019ve seen Lynch on stage. After a stint at Adobe, he joined Apple in 2013 to oversee the company\u2019s wearable and health unit and has frequently been the one to present whatever new features Apple is working on for watchOS.<\/p>\n<p><em>Bloomberg<\/em> reports Lynch joined the division earlier in the year but is now overseeing the entire unit. The outlet notes Lynch\u2019s appointment suggests Apple is likely focusing on underlying software that a self-driving car would need to navigate the road, instead of a vehicle that we could see the company release anytime soon.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Editor&#8217;s note:<\/strong> <em>This article originally appeared on <a href=\"https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/apple-appoints-kevin-lynch-car-division-223033138.html?src=rss\">Engadget<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n<div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Apple has reportedly appointed a new executive to lead the development of its secretive self-driving car division. According to Bloomberg, the company has tapped Kevin Lynch to oversee Project Titan.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":5302483,"featured_media":2200656,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"62ed9f81-2038-3083-8bee-1f1012763b69"},"categories":[17396],"tags":[291,5510526,19071,576900111],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1147877209.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3ngRpvd","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","editorialContentProvider":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[2167214],"hide_featured_image":false,"canonical_url":"https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/apple-appoints-kevin-lynch-car-division-223033138.html","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200652"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2200652"}],"version-history":[{"count":2,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200652\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2200659,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200652\/revisions\/2200659"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/guest-authors\/igor-bonifacic"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2200652&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/5302483"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\ Car","slug":"apple-car","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/5510526"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=5510526"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=5510526"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=5510526"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=5510526"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":19071,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ford\/","name":"Ford","slug":"ford","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/19071"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=19071"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=19071"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=19071"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=19071"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576900111,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tceng\/","name":"tceng","slug":"tceng","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576900111"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576900111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576900111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576900111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576900111"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200556,"date":"2021-09-09T15:10:58","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:10:58","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200556"},"modified":"2021-09-09T15:23:22","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:23:22","slug":"daily-crunch-60","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/daily-crunch-60\/","title":{"rendered":"Daily Crunch: Ray-Ban Stories smart glasses are latest step in Facebook&#8217;s AR ambitions"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>To get a roundup of TechCrunch\u2019s biggest and most important stories delivered to your inbox every day at 3 p.m. PDT, <a href=\"http:\/\/link.techcrunch.com\/join\/134\/signup-all-newsletters\">subscribe here<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>Hi friends!<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"http:\/\/twitter.com\/grg\">Greg<\/a> here again for this edition of the Daily Crunch on Thursday, September 9, 2021. <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/alex\">Alex Wilhelm<\/a> is still out on vacation for a few more days \u2026 even though he&#8217;s still tweeting a lot, which leads me to think he&#8217;s either bad at vacation or dislikes Twitter less than I do. Whatever the case, I&#8217;ll keep that daily recap goodness flowing to give you a glimpse into the biggest stories to cross our front page.<\/p>\n<h2>The TechCrunch Top 3<\/h2>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/facebook-debuts-its-ray-ban-stories-smart-sunglasses\/\"><strong>Facebook&#8217;s smart Ray-Bans:<\/strong><\/a> Five years after Snap shipped its Spectacle sunglasses, Facebook is taking a swing at the concept. But you won&#8217;t find the Facebook logo anywhere on these things (presumably because nobody on the planet wants the Facebook logo on their face). Built in partnership with Ray-Ban&#8217;s parent company, they look just like a classic pair of Wayfarers with an added bit of heft \u2026 and cameras. A white LED lights up when you&#8217;re shooting photos or videos, and near-ear speakers pipe in your tunes and phone calls. You can&#8217;t get them wet, which is great because no one wears sunglasses around places with water, like pools or beaches. Lucas Matney <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/facebooks-first-smart-glasses-make-the-case-for-face-worn-wearables\/\">reviewed them here<\/a>.<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/the-newest-roomba-gets-smarter-as-it-vacuums\/\"><strong>Roomba gets smarter:<\/strong><\/a> New Roomba incoming! The big new feature? It&#8217;ll try to detect and avoid poop your pets might have left in its path. Past models would just blast right through that mess and drag it around, leaving owners quite the horror show to come home to.<\/li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/notion-acquires-indias-automate-io-in-push-to-accelerate-product-expansion\/\">Notion acquires Automate.io:<\/a><\/strong> Notion is buying Automate.io, a startup out of India that lets you easily hook into services like Mailchimp or Gmail or Salesforce (or Notion!) and create complex automated workflows. &#8220;It&#8217;s a sizable acquisition,&#8221; Notion&#8217;s COO said without disclosing exactly how much it spent.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h2>Startups\/VC<\/h2>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/solar-powered-aircraft-developer-skydweller-aero-adds-8m-to-series-a-partners-with-palantir\/\">Skydweller Aero raises $8M for solar-powered planes:<\/a><\/strong> &#8220;Airplanes and drones today, regardless of size or fuel type, all face the same limitation: eventually they have to land.&#8221; writes Aria Alamalhodaei. &#8220;Skydweller Aero, the U.S.-Spanish aerospace startup, wants to break free from that constraint \u2026 &#8220;<\/li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/varo-bank-raises-510m-at-a-2-5b-valuation\/\">The $510M Series E:<\/a><\/strong> Varo Bank just won&#8217;t stop raising money. In June 2020, it raised $241 million, tacking on another $63 million in February 2021 because why not. Now it&#8217;s raised a staggering $510 million in a Series E round that values the company at $2.5 billion. \u201cWe didn\u2019t set out to raise this much money. It was coming in fast and furious and we were at like $510 [million] and I finally said, \u2018OK, enough,\u2019\u201d says Varo CEO Colin Walsh in a statement we can all totally relate to. Right? Anyone?<\/li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/affinity-a-relationship-intelligence-company-raises-80m-to-help-close-deals\/\">Affinity raises $80M to use machine learning to close deals:<\/a><\/strong> Who in your organization is best suited to close that deal? Can machine learning algorithms chew through your company&#8217;s data (past email interactions, calendar availability, etc.) and recommend the right person? That&#8217;s part of what Affinity is working on, and they&#8217;ve raised another $80 million to keep the ball moving and the company growing. Affinity currently has 125 employees, with plans to balloon to over 200 in the next year.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h2>Anatomy of a SPAC: Inside Better.com\u2019s ambitious plans<\/h2>\n<p>Online mortgage company Better.com isn&#8217;t waiting to complete its SPAC merger before making big moves: Today, Ryan Lawler reported that it purchased Property Partners, a U.K.-based startup that offers fractional property ownership.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s the second company Better bought in recent months: In July, it snapped up digital mortgage brokerage Trussle.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe aren\u2019t so easily categorized,\u201d said Better CEO Vishal Garg, who told Ryan that the company plans to soon expand into traditional financial services like auto loans and insurance.<\/p>\n<p>Said CFO Kevin Ryan, \u201cA lot of people have their niches in the way they\u2019re attacking this, but we feel like we\u2019re on a path to being full stack where everything\u2019s embedded in the same flow.&#8221;<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"1Ulf4597KI\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/better-mortgage-spac\/\">Anatomy of a SPAC: Inside Better.com&#8217;s ambitious plans<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Anatomy of a SPAC: Inside Better.com&#8217;s ambitious plans&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/better-mortgage-spac\/embed\/#?secret=1Ulf4597KI\" data-secret=\"1Ulf4597KI\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><em>(Extra Crunch is our membership program, which helps founders and startup teams get ahead.<\/em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe\/\"> You can sign up here<\/a><em>.)<\/em><\/p>\n<h2>Big Tech Inc.<\/h2>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/twitter-communities\/\">Twitter communities:<\/a><\/strong> Twitter keeps trying new things to make Twitter more approachable for people who don&#8217;t already have 10,000 followers. The latest experiment: Communities, or moderated social hubs, in which you can tweet with others around a shared interest. Twitter is limiting the categories, for now, to topics like dogs, weather, sneakers, skincare and astrology, and presumably hoping to stay way, way, way far away from politics for as long as possible.<\/li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/microsoft-acquires-video-creation-and-editing-software-maker-clipchamp\/\">Microsoft is buying Clipchamp:<\/a><\/strong> Ever wished Microsoft&#8217;s 365 tool suite included a video editor? Seems it&#8217;s on the way. Microsoft announced that it&#8217;s buying up Clipchamp, a web-based tool for creating\/editing videos. As for when it might be integrated into 365? TBD.<\/li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/quicken-one-of-the-first-fintechs-resold-to-another-private-equity-firm\/\">Quicken gets sold again:<\/a><\/strong> Well that was quick(en). Just a few years after being acquired by a private equity firm, Quicken is being sold off to a <em>different<\/em> private equity firm. Quicken CEO Eric Dunn shared his thoughts on the deal (plus some insights on the company&#8217;s growth as of late) with TC&#8217;s Mary Ann Azevedo.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h2>TechCrunch Experts: Growth Marketing<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2159841\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2159841\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2159841\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/GettyImages-1009465486.jpg\" alt=\"Illustration montage based on education and knowledge in blue\" width=\"1024\" height=\"643\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/GettyImages-1009465486.jpg 1500w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/GettyImages-1009465486.jpg?resize=150,94 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/GettyImages-1009465486.jpg?resize=300,188 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/GettyImages-1009465486.jpg?resize=768,482 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/GettyImages-1009465486.jpg?resize=680,427 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/GettyImages-1009465486.jpg?resize=50,31 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2159841\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.gettyimages.com\/search\/photographer?family=creative&amp;photographer=SEAN+GLADWELL\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SEAN GLADWELL <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a> \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>We\u2019re reaching out to startup founders to tell us who they turn to when they want the most up-to-date growth marketing practices. Fill out the survey <a href=\"https:\/\/oathtechevents.typeform.com\/to\/bwwIWF03\">here.<\/a><\/p>\n<p>Read one of the testimonials we\u2019ve received below!<\/p>\n<p><strong>Marketer: <\/strong>Kevin Miller, <a href=\"https:\/\/gr0.com\/\">GR0<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Recommended by: <\/strong>Leeann Schudel, <a href=\"https:\/\/thewordcounter.com\/\">The Word Counter<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Testimonial: <\/strong>\u201cSuper detailed analysis of the space and what keywords to target that would move the needle the most. There is a full dedicated SEO team that communicates weekly at the minimum and provides in-depth analysis. They are very transparent with their strategies and explain all moves they are making on their end and how it will benefit our company.
