Crunch","slug":"daily-crunch","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/961220"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=961220"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":7124,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/newsletters\/","name":"newsletters","slug":"newsletters","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/7124"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=7124"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=7124"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=7124"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=7124"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200571,"date":"2021-09-09T15:09:39","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:09:39","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200571"},"modified":"2021-09-09T17:28:48","modified_gmt":"2021-09-10T00:28:48","slug":"the-2022-chevrolet-silverado-gets-a-tech-upgrade-hands-free-trailering-and-a-new-zr2-off-road-flagship","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/the-2022-chevrolet-silverado-gets-a-tech-upgrade-hands-free-trailering-and-a-new-zr2-off-road-flagship\/","title":{"rendered":"The 2022 Chevrolet Silverado gets a tech upgrade, hands-free trailering and a new ZR2 off-road flagship"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">GM unveiled Thursday the 2022 Chevrolet Silverado, a full-sized pickup truck that received a major technology upgrade, including its hands-free Super Cruise advanced driver assistance system and an infotainment system with embedded Google services, as well as an overhauled interior. A new flagship trim, the off-road ZR2 truck with a factory-installed suspension lift, has also joined the Silverado lineup.<\/p>\n<p>The Silverado refresh comes ahead of GM&#8217;s electric vehicle offensive, which will include Chevrolet and GMC pickup trucks. <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">GM aims to deliver<\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> 30 new electric vehicles to the global market by 2025 and to transition to all zero-emission vehicles by 2035. GM said the new Silverado trims will arrive at dealerships in spring 2022.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>The exterior of the Chevy Silverado also received a refresh, including new front fascia and daytime running lights that animate when the driver walks up or away from the vehicle.\u00a0But the real change can be found in the cabin \u2014 and the hardware and software guts \u2014 of the truck.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200623\" style=\"width: 1290px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200623\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2200623 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg\" alt=\" 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2\" width=\"1280\" height=\"853\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg 1280w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-008.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200623\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2 and new headlights. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> GM<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Chevy offers the Silverado in the LT, RST, LT Trail Boss, ZR2, LTZ and High Country trims, all of which come standard with a 2.7-liter turbocharged engine \u2014 now with 420 pound-feet of torque (up 20% over the previous model). The maximum tow rating on 2WD models is 9,600 pounds. GM also made changes to smooth out shifting and give drivers more power on demand.<\/p>\n<p>The automaker also improved its 3.0 L Duramax turbocharged diesel engine to enable a max tow rating of 13,300 pounds (2WD models). Two other powertrains, the 5.3-liter V8 and the 6.2-liter V8, are also offered.<\/p>\n<p>The interior cabin has been revamped to make it feel more spacious and includes a 13.4-inch touchscreen and a new 12.3-inch configurable digital instrument cluster standard. Owners will also be able to add a rear camera mirror and a head-up display.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200602\" style=\"width: 1290px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200602\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2200602 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg\" alt=\"Chevrolet Silverado\" width=\"1280\" height=\"853\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg 1280w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/2022-Chevrolet-Silverado-ZR2-012.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200602\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The first-ever 2022 Chevrolet Silverado ZR2. <strong>Image Credits<\/strong>: GM<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Finally, the Silverado interior will be offered in new colors, seat designs and premium materials. For model trims with bucket seats, the new center console incorporates an electronic shift controller.<\/p>\n<p>Alexandre Scartezini, Chevrolet Truck&#8217;s lead interior designer, has described it as more\u00a0contemporary and refined &#8220;with a hint of Corvette influence in its design DNA.&#8221;<\/p>\n<h2>Everything Google<\/h2>\n<p>Moving in deeper inside the vehicle, aka the infotainment, users will find Google, or more specifically Android Automotive, at the heart of the operating system. This means that Google Assistant, Google Maps and Google Play are all integrated into the infotainment screen.<\/p>\n<p>Android Automotive OS shouldn&#8217;t be confused with Android Auto, which is a secondary interface that lies on top of an operating system. Android Auto is an app that runs on the user&#8217;s phone and wirelessly communicates with the vehicle&#8217;s infotainment system. Both Android Auto and its Apple CarPlay counterpart will be offered in the new Silverado. GM said the system also works with Amazon Alexa.<\/p>\n<p>Meanwhile, Android Automotive OS is modeled after its open source mobile operating system that runs on Linux. But instead of running smartphones and tablets, Google modified it so automakers could use it in their cars. Google has offered an open source version of this OS to automakers for some time. In recent years, automakers have worked with the tech company to natively build in an Android OS that is embedded with all the Google apps and services.<\/p>\n<h2>Hands-free driving<\/h2>\n<p>All of the Silverado trims come standard with six active safety features, including automatic emergency braking, lane-keeping assist and forward collision alerts, a warning if the vehicle leaves its lane, a following distance indicator, automatic high beams and front pedestrian braking.<\/p>\n<p>The big change is the addition of the automaker&#8217;s Super Cruise hands-free driver-assistance technology, which will be an available option on the High Country trim. Importantly, the system can be used even while trailering. Certain features of Super Cruise like automatic lane changing and lane change on demand will be restricted if the truck is towing.<\/p>\n<p>Super Cruise uses a combination of lidar map data, high-precision GPS, cameras and radar sensors, as well as a driver attention system, which monitors the person behind the wheel to ensure they&#8217;re paying attention. Unlike Tesla&#8217;s Autopilot driver assistance system, users of Super Cruise do not need to have their hands on the wheel. However, their eyes must remain directed straight ahead.<\/p>\n<p>While GM has steadily improved Super Cruise since its introduction in 2017, for years it was limited to its luxury Cadillac brand and restricted to certain divided highways. That began to change in 2019 when GM announced plans to expand it to more models and use cases. The system can be activated on more than 200,000 miles of roads in the United States and Canada.<\/p>\n<p>The Silverado will offer other trailer assistance features, including one that will alert drivers to vehicles in their blind spot.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>GM unveiled Thursday the 2022 Chevrolet Silverado, a full-sized pickup truck that received a major technology upgrade, including its hands-free Super Cruise advanced driver assistance system and an infotainment system with embedded Google services, as well as an overhauled interior. A new flagship trim, the off-road ZR2 truck with a factory-installed suspension lift, has also =81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200083,"date":"2021-09-09T15:09:28","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:09:28","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200083"},"modified":"2021-09-09T15:09:28","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:09:28","slug":"what-chinas-new-data-privacy-law-means-for-us-tech-firms","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/what-chinas-new-data-privacy-law-means-for-us-tech-firms\/","title":{"rendered":"What China&#8217;s new data privacy law means for US tech firms"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Scott W. Pink<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/omelvenymyers\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\t<a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/scott-pink\/\">Scott W. Pink<\/a> is special counsel in O\u2019Melveny\u2019s Data Security &amp; Privacy practice based in Silicon Valley. He advises technology, media, entertainment and a variety of companies on issues of cybersecurity and privacy, IP  counseling; social media law; and advertising, marketing, and promotions law. \t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">China enacted a sweeping<\/span> new data privacy law on August 20 that will dramatically impact how tech companies can operate in the country. Officially called the Personal Information Protection Law of the People\u2019s Republic of China (PIPL), the law is the first national data privacy statute passed in China.<\/p>\n<p>Modeled after the European Union\u2019s General Data Protection Regulation, the PIPL imposes protections and restrictions on data collection and transfer that companies both inside and outside of China will need to address. It is particularly focused on apps using personal information to target consumers or offer them different prices on products and services, and preventing the transfer of personal information to other countries with fewer protections for security.<\/p>\n<p>The PIPL, slated to take effect on November 1, 2021, does not give companies a lot of time to prepare. Those that already follow GDPR practices, particularly if they&#8217;ve implemented it globally, will have an easier time complying with China&#8217;s new requirements. But firms that have not implemented GDPR practices will need to consider adopting a similar approach. In addition, U.S. companies will need to consider the new restrictions on the transfer of personal information from China to the U.S.<\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--right\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tImplementation and compliance with the PIPL is a much more significant task for companies that have not implemented GDPR principles.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s a deep dive into the PIPL and what it means for tech firms:<\/p>\n<h2>New data handling requirements<strong><br \/>\n<\/strong><\/h2>\n<p>The PIPL introduces perhaps the most stringent set of requirements and protections for data privacy in the world (this includes special requirements relating to processing personal information by governmental agencies that will not be addressed here). The law broadly relates to all kinds of information, recorded by electronic or other means, related to identified or identifiable natural persons, but excludes anonymized information.<\/p>\n<p>The following are some of the key new requirements for handling people&#8217;s personal information in China that will affect tech businesses:<\/p>\n<h3>Extra-territorial application of the China law<\/h3>\n<p>Historically, China regulations have only been applied to activities inside the country. The PIPL is similar in applying the law to personal information handling activities within Chinese borders. However, similar to GDPR, it also expands its application to the handling of personal information outside China if the following conditions are met:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li>Where the purpose is to provide products or services to people inside China.<\/li>\n<li>Where analyzing or assessing activities of people inside China.<\/li>\n<li>Other circumstances provided in laws or administrative regulations.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>For example, if you are a U.S.-based company selling products to consumers in China, you may be subject to the China data privacy law even if you do not have a facility or operations there.<\/p>\n<h3>Data handling principles<\/h3>\n<p>The PIPL introduces principles of transparency, purpose and data minimization: Companies can only collect personal information for a clear, reasonable and disclosed purpose, and to the smallest scope for realizing the purpose, and retain the data only for the period necessary to fulfill that purpose. Any information handler is also required to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the data it handles to avoid any negative impact on personal rights and interests.<\/p>\n<p><div collection and transfer that companies both inside and outside of China will need to om\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":449557076,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/china\/","name":"China","slug":"china","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557076"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557076"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557076"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557076"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557076"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":8159,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/computer-security\/","name":"computer Column","slug":"ec-column","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576846312"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576846312"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576846312"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576846312"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576846312"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576894756,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ec-east-asia\/","name":"EC East Asia","slug":"ec-east-asia","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576894756"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576894756"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576894756"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576894756"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576894756"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":6474,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/encryption\/","name":"encryption","slug":"encryption","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/6474"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=6474"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=6474"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=6474"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=6474"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":46740,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/european-union\/","name":"european union","slug":"european-union","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/46740"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=46740"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=46740"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=46740"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=46740"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449551932,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/general-data-protection-regulation\/","name":"General Data Protection Regulation","slug":"general-data-protection-regulation","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449551932"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449551932"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449551932"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449551932"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449551932"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[{"id":576796356,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/extracrunch\/market-analysis\/","name":"Market Analysis","slug":"market-analysis","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2195527,"date":"2021-09-09T14:31:50","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T21:31:50","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2195527"},"modified":"2021-09-09T15:13:44","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:13:44","slug":"squad-mobility-eyes-shared-platforms-as-target-for-its-compact-solar-electric-quadricycle","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/squad-mobility-eyes-shared-platforms-as-target-for-its-compact-solar-electric-quadricycle\/","title":{"rendered":"Squad Mobility eyes shared platforms as target for its compact solar electric quadricycle"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Squad Mobility&#8217;s vision of the perfect urban vehicle is a low-cost EV equipped with solar panels, swappable batteries and enough zip and range in its diminutive 6.5-foot package to meet the needs of city drivers.<\/p>\n<p>The early-stage Dutch startup, which recently revealed the final design of its quadricycle, is now assembling working prototypes in Breda, the Netherlands. Squad has said the vehicle will have a base price of \u20ac5,750 ($6,790), excluding taxes. That price goes up if buyers want to add features like removable doors, air conditioning, heating and extra batteries.<\/p>\n<p>Squad plans to present the prototypes this fall, <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Robert Hoevers, CEO and co-founder of the company, said in a recent interview. Pre-production is also expected to begin this year with a goal to start <\/span>delivering the car at the end of 2022.<\/p>\n<p>Squad, like so many other new entrants to the EV car scene, will need more funds to reach its target.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"tFIdUYEh9I\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/12\/sono-motors-plans-to-license-the-tech-that-powers-its-solar-electric-car\/\">Sono Motors plans to license the tech that powers its solar electric car<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Sono Motors plans to license the tech that powers its solar electric car&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/12\/sono-motors-plans-to-license-the-tech-that-powers-its-solar-electric-car\/embed\/#?secret=tFIdUYEh9I\" data-secret=\"tFIdUYEh9I\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">In June, the company <\/span><a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/pulse\/squad-mobility-closes-investment-partnership-bloomit-squadmobility\/\">raised an undisclosed amount from Bloomit Ventures<\/a><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">. To reach its production goals, Hoevers estimates Squad will need an additional \u20ac3.5 million ($4.1 million) for its next round, and then another \u20ac8 million ($9.6 million) to be able to deliver the first Squads. The company has not yet announced a round publicly, but says it&#8217;s in talks with various interested parties.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Interested customers can go on <a href=\"https:\/\/www.squadmobility.com\/\">Squad&#8217;s website<\/a> and pay a \u20ac5 reserve fee, but where Squad really sees its path to market is with shared mobility companies. The startup says it is in talks with a range of micromobility and car-sharing operators that might be interested in diversifying their fleets with a compact, smart vehicle.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The Squad, which is a combination of the words &#8220;solar&#8221; and &#8220;quadricycle,&#8221; seats two, punches up to 30 miles per hour and is fueled by two swappable batteries with a capacity of around 1.6 Kwh each and a collective range of about 62 miles. This is similar to the battery capacity and range of electric mopeds.<\/p>\n<p>For the average European city driver, that should be enough range. Squad also installed a 250-watt solar panel to the vehicle, which the company says adds another 12 miles per day given the amount of sun Europe tends to get.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2196065\" style=\"width: 4010px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2196065\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2196065 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"4000\" height=\"2000\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg 4000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg?resize=150,75 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg?resize=300,150 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg?resize=768,384 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg?resize=680,340 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg?resize=1536,768 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg?resize=2048,1024 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Squad-Charging-Station.jpg?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 4000px) 100vw, 4000px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2196065\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Rendering of a Squad charging station for swappable batteries that can be used by shared mobility operators. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Squad Mobility<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Squad is coming onto the scene at the intersection of new mobility categories and EV charging innovation, which could be appealing to shared mobility operators looking to solve more use cases.<\/p>\n<p>Shared micromobility companies are beginning to add electric mopeds to their fleets of e-scooters and e-bikes. The Squad could appeal to operators that want to appeal to a broader demographic, and one specifically more comfortable in a four-wheeled vehicle.<\/p>\n<p>The potential savings from harnessing the power of the sun could attract operators as well. In the micromobility world, the labor costs associated with swapping batteries or charging vehicles represent a roadblock to profitability. A vehicle that&#8217;s constantly on a bit of a charge, at least during the daylight hours, might help alleviate that pain point.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The idea is not to drive directly on solar,&#8221;<span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> Hoevers\u00a0<\/span>told TechCrunch. &#8220;The idea is to buffer the batteries with solar and then drive on the batteries. The sun is more or less drip charging the battery throughout the day, which is actually a very healthy way of charging. You don&#8217;t want to top off your batteries to 100%. You want to keep them at around 50% to 60% all the time for a longer battery life.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Hoevers<\/span> said Squad has been in talks with shared micromobility providers to pitch the quadricycle, and has found that most dockless vehicles see about four to five rides per day and drive about 36 to 38 miles per day, numbers that TechCrunch confirmed with a few micromobility operators and that are well within the range of the Squad car.<\/p>\n<p>Squad also intends to equip its vehicles with cameras, sensors and other smart features like remote diagnostics and maintenance, which will make the company more attractive to shared operators looking for a fleet that can be integrated into its management platforms. Hoevers also says he and his co-founder, Chris Klok, have used their collective 40 years of experience in mobility and shared past at long range solar EV company Lightyear to develop a strong CAN bus and drivetrain upon which new features can be added.<\/p>\n<p>Whether Squad ends up selling fleets to micromobility platforms or car-sharing platforms might depend on the category in which the vehicle ends up. With its current speed and weight, the Squad car will be in the L6e category for light four-wheeled vehicles.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#8220;There are interesting cost and tax benefits in this segment,&#8221; said Hoevers. &#8220;For example, there is no congestion charge, no road tax, no parking fees, low insurance fees and no car driving license needed in most markets.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Hoevers said the company is also considering producing a more powerful L7 that can go top speeds of around 45 miles per hour, which might be better for cities with more hills.<\/p>\n<h2>The competition<\/h2>\n<p>Squad isn&#8217;t the only company that has added solar panels to its electric vehicles. Germany-based startup Sono Motors told TechCrunch that it&#8217;s on track to begin deliveries of its electric Sion vehicle by 2023.\u00a0The<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/12\/sono-motors-plans-to-license-the-tech-that-powers-its-solar-electric-car\/\"> vehicle&#8217;s exterior is composed of hundreds of solar cells<\/a> that have been integrated into polymer instead of glass and can add up to nearly 22 miles of extra battery life per day.<\/p>\n<p>Although the Sion has not yet been released, the Sono app is already inviting owners of the vehicle to engage in a sort of car sharing that&#8217;s reminiscent of Airbnb for Sions in order to make use of vehicles that otherwise sit parked and useless for most of the day. As of Thursday, <a href=\"https:\/\/sonomotors.com\/en\/press\/press-releases\/sono-motors-carsharing-service-expansion\/\">Sono is expanding this vision to allow any car to be shared via the Sono app<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Aptera Motors, a California company that has promised to roll out the &#8220;<a href=\"https:\/\/www.washingtonpost.com\/climate-solutions\/interactive\/2021\/solar-car\/\">first mass-produced solar car<\/a>&#8221; this year, raised $4 million in a <a href=\"https:\/\/www.autoweek.com\/news\/green-cars\/a34869242\/the-aptera-ev-is-back-and-claims-up-to-1000-miles-of-range\/\">Series A this February<\/a> that it is using to pay for fiberglass, carbon fiber and batteries for its spaceship-looking tricycle. Aptera says its vehicle, which is available for pre-order and could cost anywhere between $25,900 and $46,900, will be built with 34 square feet of solar cells that can add an additional 40 miles of battery capacity on a clear day.<\/p>\n<p>Each of the players in the solar-powered EV space have differences in tech, path to market and style, but they&#8217;re all potentially finding ways to ease the strain on the electrical grid.<\/p>\n<p>In the Netherlands, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.pewresearch.org\/fact-tank\/2021\/06\/07\/todays-electric-vehicle-market-slow-growth-in-u-s-faster-in-china-europe\/#:~:text=Last%20year%2C%20about%2064%2C300%20plug,the%20U.S.%20new%2Dcar%20market.\">new electric cars make up 25% of total market share<\/a>, and that number will only increase. It might not be feasible in the long run for all of those vehicles to each plug into the grid to power up, especially when industries across sectors are beginning to electrify.<\/p>\n<p>While it&#8217;s clear that the technology isn&#8217;t there yet for vehicles to run purely on solar, Squad and other companies like it are laying the groundwork for future solar technology.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"h9dvz934sU\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/04\/revels-frank-reig-shares-how-he-built-his-business-and-what-hes-planning\/\">Revel&#8217;s Frank Reig shares how he built his business and what he&#8217;s planning<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Revel&#8217;s Frank Reig shares how he built his business and what he&#8217;s planning&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/04\/revels-frank-reig-shares-how-he-built-his-business-and-what-hes-planning\/embed\/#?secret=h9dvz934sU\" data-secret=\"h9dvz934sU\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Squad Mobility&#8217;s vision of the perfect urban vehicle is a low-cost EV equipped with solar panels, swappable batteries and enough zip and range in its diminutive 6.5-foot package to meet the needs of city drivers. The early-stage Dutch startup, which recently revealed the final design of its quadricycle, is now assembling working prototypes in Breda, mobility","slug":"squad-mobility","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576914811"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576914811"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576914811"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576914811"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576914811"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200044,"date":"2021-09-09T14:30:21","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T21:30:21","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200044"},"modified":"2021-09-09T14:59:33","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T21:59:33","slug":"uk-dials-up-the-spin-on-data-reform-claiming-simplified-rules-will-drive-responsible-data-sharing","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/uk-dials-up-the-spin-on-data-reform-claiming-simplified-rules-will-drive-responsible-data-sharing\/","title":{"rendered":"UK dials up the spin on data reform, claiming &#8216;simplified&#8217; rules will drive &#8216;responsible&#8217; data sharing"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The U.K. government has announced a consultation on plans to shake up the national data protection regime, as it looks at how to diverge from European Union rules following Brexit.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s also a year since the U.K. published a national data strategy in which said it <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/09\/uk-wants-pandemic-levels-of-data-sharing-to-be-the-new-normal\/\">wanted pandemic levels of data sharing<\/a> to become Britain&#8217;s new normal.<\/p>\n<p>The Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCPS) has today trailed an incoming reform of the information commissioner&#8217;s office &#8212; saying it wants to broaden the ICO&#8217;s remit to &#8220;champion sectors and businesses that are using personal data in new, innovative and responsible ways to benefit people\u2019s lives&#8221;; and promising &#8220;simplified&#8221; rules to encourage the use of data for research which &#8220;benefit&#8217;s people&#8217;s lives&#8221;, such as in the field of healthcare.<\/p>\n<p>It also wants a new structure for the regulator &#8212; including the creation of an independent board and chief executive for the ICO, to mirror the governance structures of other regulators such as the Competition and Markets Authority, Financial Conduct Authority and Ofcom.<\/p>\n<p>Additionally, it said the data reform consultation will consider how the new regime can help mitigate the risks around algorithmic bias &#8212; something the EU is already moving to legislate on, setting out <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/04\/21\/europe-lays-out-plan-for-risk-based-ai-rules-to-boost-trust-and-uptake\/\">a risk-based proposal for regulating applications of AI<\/a> back in April.<\/p>\n<p>Which means the U.K. risks being left lagging if it&#8217;s only going to concern itself with a narrow focus on &#8220;bias mitigation&#8221;, rather than considering the wider sweep of how AI is intersecting with and influencing its citizens&#8217; lives.<\/p>\n<p>In a press release announcing the consultation, DCMS highlights an artificial intelligence partnership involving Moorfields Eye Hospital and the University College London Institute of Ophthalmology, which kicked off back in <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/07\/05\/deepmind-partners-with-nhs-eye-hospital-to-conduct-ai-research\/\">2016<\/a>, as an example of the kinds of beneficial data sharing it wants to encourage. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nature.com\/articles\/s41591-020-0867-7\">Last year<\/a> the researchers reported that their AI had been able to predict the development of wet age-related macular degeneration more accurately than clinicians.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The partnership also involved (Google-owned) DeepMind and now Google Health &#8212; although the government&#8217;s PR doesn&#8217;t make mention of the tech giant&#8217;s involvement. It&#8217;s an interesting omission, given that DeepMind&#8217;s name is also attached to a notorious U.K. patient data-sharing scandal, which saw another London-based NHS Trust (the Royal Free) sanctioned by the ICO,<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2017\/05\/15\/deepmind-nhs-health-data-deal-had-no-lawful-basis\/\">\u00a0in 2017<\/a>, for improperly sharing patient data with the Google-owned company during the development phase of a clinician support app (which <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/26\/google-confirms-its-pulling-the-plug-on-streams-its-uk-clinician-support-app\/\">Google is now in the process of discontinuing<\/a>).<\/p>\n<p>DCMS may be keen to avoid spelling out that its goal for the data reforms &#8212; aka to &#8220;remove unnecessary barriers to responsible data use&#8221; &#8212; could end up making it easier for commercial entities like Google to get their hands on U.K. citizens&#8217; medical records.<\/p>\n<p>The <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/society\/2021\/aug\/22\/nhs-data-grab-on-hold-as-millions-opt-out\">sizeable public backlash<\/a> over the most recent government attempt to requisition NHS users&#8217; medical records &#8212; for vaguely defined &#8220;research&#8221; purposes (aka the &#8220;General Practice Data for Planning and Research&#8221;, or GPDPR, scheme) &#8212; suggests that a government-enabled big-health-data-free-for-all might not be so popular with U.K. voters.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The government\u2019s data reforms will provide clarity around the rules for the use of personal data for research purposes, laying the groundwork for more scientific and medical breakthroughs,&#8221; is how DCMS&#8217; PR skirts the sensitive health data sharing topic.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"bxFLpJ68CU\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/06\/after-years-of-inaction-against-adtech-uks-ico-calls-for-browser-level-controls-to-fix-cookie-fatigue\/\">After years of inaction against adtech, UK&#8217;s ICO calls for browser-level controls to fix &#8216;cookie fatigue&#8217;<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;After years of inaction against adtech, UK&#8217;s ICO calls for browser-level controls to fix &#8216;cookie fatigue&#8217;&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/06\/after-years-of-inaction-against-adtech-uks-ico-calls-for-browser-level-controls-to-fix-cookie-fatigue\/embed\/#?secret=bxFLpJ68CU\" data-secret=\"bxFLpJ68CU\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Elsewhere there&#8217;s talk of &#8220;reinforc[ing] the responsibility of businesses to keep personal information safe, while empowering them to grow and innovate&#8221; &#8212; so that sounds like a yes to data security but what about individual privacy and control over what happens to your information?<\/p>\n<p>The government seems to be saying that will depend on other aims &#8212; principally economic interests attached to the U.K.&#8217;s ability to conduct data-driven research or secure trade deals with other countries that don&#8217;t have the same (current) high U.K. standards of data protection.<\/p>\n<p>There are some purely populist flourishes here too &#8212; with DCMS couching its ambition for a data regime &#8220;based on common sense, not box ticking&#8221; &#8212; and flagging up plans to beef up penalties for nuisance calls and text messages. Because, sure, who doesn&#8217;t like the sound of a crackdown on spam?<\/p>\n<p>Except spam text messages and nuisance calls are a pretty quaint concern to zero in on in an era of apps and data-driven, democracy-disrupting mass surveillance &#8212; which was something the outgoing information commissioner <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/07\/11\/facebook-under-fresh-political-pressure-as-uk-watchdog-calls-for-ethical-pause-of-ad-ops\/\">raised as a major issue of concern<\/a> during her tenure at the ICO.<\/p>\n<p>The same populist anti-spam messaging has already been deployed by ministers to attack the need to obtain internet users&#8217; consent for dropping tracking cookies &#8212; which the digital minister Oliver Dowden <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/06\/after-years-of-inaction-against-adtech-uks-ico-calls-for-browser-level-controls-to-fix-cookie-fatigue\/\">recently suggested<\/a> he wants to do away with &#8212; for all but &#8220;high risk&#8221; purposes.<\/p>\n<p>Having a system of rights wrapping people&#8217;s data that gives them a say over (and a stake in) how it can be used appears to be being reframed in the government&#8217;s messaging as irresponsible or even non-patriotic &#8212; with DCMS pushing the notion that such rights stand in the way of more important economic or highly generalized &#8220;social&#8221; goals.<\/p>\n<p>Not that it has presented any evidence for that &#8212; or even that the U.K.&#8217;s current data protection regime got in the way of (the very ample) <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/05\/uks-covid-19-health-data-contracts-with-google-and-palantir-finally-emerge\/\">data sharing during COVID-19<\/a>&#8230; While negative uses of people&#8217;s information are being condensed in DCMS&#8217; messaging to the narrowest possible definition &#8212; of spam that&#8217;s visible to an individual &#8212; never mind how that person got targeted with the nuisance calls\/spam texts in the first place.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"mIS0RJvELX\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/05\/uks-covid-19-health-data-contracts-with-google-and-palantir-finally-emerge\/\">UK&#8217;s COVID-19 health data contracts with Google and Palantir finally emerge<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;UK&#8217;s COVID-19 health data contracts with Google and Palantir finally emerge&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/05\/uks-covid-19-health-data-contracts-with-google-and-palantir-finally-emerge\/embed\/#?secret=mIS0RJvELX\" data-secret=\"mIS0RJvELX\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>The government is taking its customary &#8220;cake and eat it&#8221; approach to spinning its reform plan &#8212; claiming it will both &#8220;protect&#8221; people&#8217;s data while also trumpeting the importance of making it really easy for citizens&#8217; information to be handed off to anyone who wants it, so long as they can claim they&#8217;re doing some kind of &#8220;innovation&#8221;, while also larding its PR with canned quotes dubbing the plan &#8220;bold&#8221; and &#8220;ambitious&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>So while DCMS&#8217; announcement says the reform will &#8220;maintain&#8221; the U.K.&#8217;s (currently) world-leading data protection standards, it directly rows back &#8212; saying the new regime will (merely) &#8220;build on&#8221; a few broad-brush &#8220;key elements&#8221; of the current rules (specifically it says it will keep &#8220;principles around data processing, people\u2019s data rights and mechanisms for supervision and enforcement&#8221;).<\/p>\n<p>Clearly the devil will be in the detail of the proposals which are due to be published tomorrow morning. So expect more analysis to debunk the spin soon.<\/p>\n<p>But in one specific trailed change DCMS says it wants to move away from a &#8220;one-size-fits-all&#8221; approach to data protection compliance &#8212; and &#8220;allow organisations to demonstrate compliance in ways more appropriate to their circumstances, while still protecting citizens\u2019 personal data to a high standard&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>That implies that smaller data-mining operations &#8212; DCMS&#8217;s PR uses the example of a hairdresser&#8217;s but plenty of startups can employ fewer staff than the average barber&#8217;s shop &#8212; may be able to expect to get a pass to ignore those &#8216;high standards&#8217; in the future.<\/p>\n<p>Which suggests the U.K.&#8217;s &#8220;high standards&#8221; may, under Dowden&#8217;s watch, end up resembling more of a Swiss Cheese&#8230;<\/p>\n<h2>Data protection is a &#8220;how to, not a don&#8217;t do&#8221;&#8230;<\/h2>\n<p>The man who is likely to become the U.K.&#8217;s next information commissioner, New Zealand&#8217;s privacy commissioner John Edwards, was <a href=\"https:\/\/parliamentlive.tv\/Event\/Index\/1508ef32-ec1d-4295-a5bf-aa8cd8211e7a\">taking questions from a parliamentary committee<\/a> earlier today, as MPs considered whether to support his appointment to the role.<\/p>\n<p>If he&#8217;s confirmed in the job, Edwards will be responsible for implementing whatever new data regime the government cooks up.<\/p>\n<p>Under questioning, he rejected the notion that the U.K.&#8217;s current data protection regime presents a barrier to data sharing &#8212; arguing that laws like GDPR should rather be seen as a &#8220;how to&#8221; and an &#8220;enabler&#8221; for innovation.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;I would take issue with the dichotomy that you presented [about privacy vs data-sharing],&#8221; he told the committee chair. &#8220;I don&#8217;t believe that policymakers and businesses and governments are faced with a choice of share or keep faith with data protection. Data protection laws and privacy laws would not be necessary if it wasn&#8217;t necessary to share information. These are two sides of the same coin.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The UK DPA [data protection act] and UK GDPR they are a &#8216;how to&#8217; &#8212; not a &#8216;don&#8217;t do&#8217;. And I think the UK and many jurisdictions have really finally learned that lesson through the COVID-19 crisis. It has been absolutely necessary to have good quality information available, minute by minute. And to move across different organizations where it needs to go, without friction. And there are times when data protection laws and privacy laws introduce friction and I think that what you&#8217;ve seen in the UK is that when it needs to things can happen quickly.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>He also suggested that plenty of economic gains could be achieved for the U.K. with some minor tweaks to current rules, rather than a more radical reboot being necessary. (Though clearly setting the rules won&#8217;t be up to him; his job will be enforcing whatever new regime is decided.)<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;If we can, in the administration of a law which at the moment looks very much like the UK GDPR, that gives great latitude for different regulatory approaches &#8212; if I can turn that dial just a couple of points that can make the difference of billions of pounds to the UK economy and thousands of jobs so we don&#8217;t need to be throwing out the statute book and starting again &#8212; there is plenty of scope to be making improvements under the current regime,&#8221; he told MPs. &#8220;Let alone when we start with a fresh sheet of paper if that&#8217;s what the government chooses to do.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>TechCrunch asked another Edwards (no relation) &#8212; Newcastle University&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lilianedwards\">Lilian Edwards<\/a>, professor of law, innovation and society &#8212; for her thoughts on the government&#8217;s direction of travel, as signalled by DCMS&#8217; pre-proposal-publication spin, and she expressed similar concerns about the logic driving the government to argue it needs to rip up the existing standards.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThe entire scheme of data protection is to balance fundamental rights with the free flow of data. Economic concerns have never been ignored, and the current scheme, which we\u2019ve had in essence since 1998, has struck a good balance. The great things we did with data during COVID-19 were done completely legally &#8212; and with no great difficulty under the existing rules &#8212; so that isn\u2019t a reason to change them,&#8221; she told us.<\/p>\n<p>She also took issue with the plan to reshape the ICO &#8220;as a quango whose primary job is to &#8216;drive economic growth&#8217; &#8221; &#8212; pointing out that DCMS&#8217; PR fails to include any mention of privacy or fundamental rights, and arguing that &#8220;creating an entirely new regulator isn\u2019t likely to do much for the &#8216;public trust&#8217; that\u2019s seen as declining in almost every poll.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>She also suggested the government is glossing over the real economic damage that would hit the U.K. if the EU decides its &#8220;reformed&#8221; standards are no longer essentially equivalent to the bloc&#8217;s. &#8220;[It&#8217;s] hard to see much concern for adequacy here; which will, for sure, be reviewed, to our detriment &#8212; prejudicing 43% of our trade for a few low value trade deals and some hopeful sell offs of NHS data (again, likely to take a wrecking ball to trust judging by the GPDPR scandal).&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>She described the goal of regulating algorithmic bias as &#8220;applaudable&#8221; &#8212; but also flagged the risk of the U.K. falling behind other jurisdictions which are taking a broader look at how to regulate artificial intelligence.<\/p>\n<p>Per DCMS&#8217; press release, the government seems to be intending for an existing advisory body, called the Centre for Data Ethics and Innovation (CDEI), to have a key role in supporting its policymaking in this area &#8212; saying that the body will <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">focus on &#8220;enabling trustworthy use of data and AI in the real-world&#8221;.\u00a0<\/span>However it has still not appointed a new CDEI chair to replace Roger Taylor &#8212; with only an interim chair appointment (and some new advisors) announced today.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The world has moved on since CDEI\u2019s work in this area,&#8221; argued Edwards. &#8220;We realise now that regulating the harmful effects of AI has to be considered in the round with other regulatory tools not just data protection. The proposed EU AI Regulation is not without flaw but goes far further than data protection in mandating better quality training sets, and more transparent systems to be built from scratch. If the UK is serious about regulating it has to look at the global models being floated but right now it looks like its main concerns are insular, short-sighted and populist.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Patient data privacy advocacy group MedConfidential, which has frequently locked horns with the government over its approach to data protection, also queried DCMS&#8217; continued attachment to the CDEI for shaping policymaking in such a crucial area &#8212; pointing to last year&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/blogs.lse.ac.uk\/impactofsocialsciences\/2020\/08\/26\/fk-the-algorithm-what-the-world-can-learn-from-the-uks-a-level-grading-fiasco\/\">biased algorithm exam grading scandal<\/a>, which happened under Taylor&#8217;s watch.<\/p>\n<p>(NB: Taylor was also the Ofqual chair, and his resignation from that post in December cited a &#8220;difficult summer&#8221;, even as his departure from the CDEI leaves an awkward hole now&#8230; )<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThe culture and leadership of CDEI led to the A-Levels algorithm, why should anyone in government have any confidence in what they say next?&#8221; said MedConfidential&#8217;s Sam Smith.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The U.K. government has announced a consultation on plans to shake up the national data protection regime, as it looks at how to diverge from European Union rules following Brexit. It&#8217;s also a year since the U.K. published a national data strategy in which said it wanted pandemic levels of data sharing to become Britain&#8217;s [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":39990176,"featured_media":1989672,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"fe5c9c37-9cf4-32b6-8949-44562f8ed8d6"},"categories":[424613844,449557100,13217,426637499],"tags":[12374,446473119,576602352,1131271,210341831,81,155052,1460,426332187,134659,449550368,449547542,576803606,3279,576918441,576602794,449557035],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-930848198.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/2X4bY31","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","editorialContentProvider":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[39990176],"hide_featured_image":false,"canonical_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/uk-dials-up-the-spin-on-data-reform-claiming-simplified-rules-will-drive-responsible-data-sharing\/","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200044"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2200044"}],"version-history":[{"count":50,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200044\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2200617,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200044\/revisions\/2200617"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/39990176"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2200044&action Natasha holds a First Class degree in English from Cambridge University, and an MA in journalism from Goldsmiths College, University of London.<\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/01\/575a81841b1b431463585c830bffd373.jpg.jpg","twitter":"riptari","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/39990176"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users"}]}}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"id":1989672,"date":"2020-05-15T13:51:15","slug":"thumb-touch-on-red-emergency-stop-switch-button","type":"attachment","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/17\/the-great-reset\/thumb-touch-on-red-emergency-stop-switch-button\/","title":{"rendered":"reset Thumb touch on red emergency stop switch button."},"author":133574325,"license":{"source_key":"getty commissioner's office","slug":"information-commissioners-office","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/426332187"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=426332187"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=426332187"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=426332187"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=426332187"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":134659,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/john-edwards\/","name":"John Edwards","slug":"john-edwards","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/134659"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=134659"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=134659"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=134659"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=134659"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200417,"date":"2021-09-09T13:30:30","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T20:30:30","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200417"},"modified":"2021-09-09T13:42:27","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T20:42:27","slug":"donotpays-robot-lawyer-can-now-help-report-potholes-or-fallen-trees-to-the-city-file-damage-claims","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/donotpays-robot-lawyer-can-now-help-report-potholes-or-fallen-trees-to-the-city-file-damage-claims\/","title":{"rendered":"DoNotPay&#8217;s &#8216;robot lawyer&#8217; can now help report potholes or fallen trees to the city, file damage claims"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Tired of swerving around the same pothole every day but don&#8217;t know how to report it to your city? Already reported it but feel like said report was fired off into the ether, never to be read much less fixed?<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"http:\/\/donotpay.com\">DoNotPay<\/a>, a company that makes annoying processes less annoying through automation, might be able to help. Their &#8220;robot lawyer,&#8221; as the company calls it, started out as a service meant to help people more easily fight parking tickets. Over time it&#8217;s learned a bunch of new tricks, like helping users end tough-to-cancel subscriptions, get refunds they&#8217;re owed and more.<\/p>\n<p>Its latest thing? Helping users report issues like potholes, fallen trees\/branches and broken streetlights to their city government \u2014 and if said issue damaged your property or cost you money, it&#8217;ll help get you paid back.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200448\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200448\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2200448\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"333\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png 2304w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?resize=150,73 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?resize=300,147 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?resize=768,376 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?resize=680,333 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?resize=1536,752 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?resize=2048,1003 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs.png?resize=50,24 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200448\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> DoNotPay<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>&#8220;It just seems so unfair that if an ordinary American is driving down the street with a broken tail light, the government could give them a ticket and charge them money \u2026 but if there&#8217;s a pothole in the road, you can&#8217;t get money from the government,&#8221; says DoNotPay founder Joshua Browder. &#8220;So we&#8217;ve decided to create a product that is like a fix-it ticket for the government.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>When you start the process of reporting a city issue with DoNotPay, you&#8217;re given two options: report the issue or claim compensation. The first finds the correct place to report an issue in your city, then their chatbot gathers all the info it needs and sends it over to the city with your contact info. The second walks you through the small claims court process; their robot lawyer can&#8217;t represent you, but it&#8217;ll generate the documents you need and try to tell you everything you need to know to make your case.<\/p>\n<p>DoNotPay started out as something of a side project but quickly grew into something more.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;When I was studying at Stanford, I got a bunch of parking tickets,&#8221; Browder tells me. &#8220;I learned \u2026 I was a terrible driver. But I also learned that the government issues tickets to make money, not necessarily to punish people. So I created the first version for fun \u2014 to help myself and my friends. Within two days of creating it, one of my friends posted it on reddit and it went completely viral internationally. I went from 10 cases on day one to like \u2026 50,000. All this made me realize that this is bigger than just a side project. It really taps into what people hate: being ripped off. So I&#8217;ve decided to devote all my time to pursuing that over the past six years.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Browder tells me these new reporting features are live now, currently work in the top 50-or-so biggest US cities, and are included in DoNotPay&#8217;s standard subscription price ($36 for three months.)<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200449\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200449\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2200449\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs-2.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"643\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs-2.png 1454w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs-2.png?resize=150,142 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs-2.png?resize=300,283 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs-2.png?resize=768,726 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs-2.png?resize=680,643 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/donotpay-city-repairs-2.png?resize=50,47 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200449\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> DoNotPay<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Tired of swerving around the same pothole every day but don&#8217;t know how to report it to your city? Already reported it but feel like said report was fired off into the ether, never to be read much less fixed? DoNotPay, a company that makes annoying processes less annoying through automation, might be able to [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":5188242,"featured_media":2085535,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"da94ea04-94a5-3a15-9176-83ee3869ce69"},"categories":[17396],"tags":[449550965],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/12\/do-not-pay.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3troyVS","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","editorialContentProvider":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[5188242],"hide_featured_image":false,"canonical_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/donotpays-robot-lawyer-can-now-help-report-potholes-or-fallen-trees-to-the-city-file-damage-claims\/","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200417"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2200417"}],"version-history":[{"count":10,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200417\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2200583,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200417\/revisions\/2200583"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/5188242"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2200417&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/5188242"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/2085535"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media?parent=2200417"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories?post=2200417"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags?post=2200417"},{"taxonomy":"_tc_cb_tag_taxonomy","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/crunchbase_tag?post=2200417"},{"taxonomy":"tc_stories_tax","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_stories_tax?post=2200417"},{"taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category?post=2200417"},{"taxonomy":"tc_event","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event?post=2200417"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]},"_embedded":{"authors":[{"id":5188242,"name":"Greg
