wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":449550965,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/donotpay\/","name":"DoNotPay","slug":"donotpay","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449550965"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449550965"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449550965"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449550965"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449550965"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200541,"date":"2021-09-09T13:27:35","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T20:27:35","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200541"},"modified":"2021-09-09T14:10:22","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T21:10:22","slug":"twitter-introduces-a-new-label-that-allows-the-good-bots-to-identify-themselves","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/twitter-introduces-a-new-label-that-allows-the-good-bots-to-identify-themselves\/","title":{"rendered":"Twitter introduces a new label that allows the \u2018good bots\u2019 to identify themselves"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Twitter today is introducing a new feature that will allow accounts to self-identify as bots by adding a label to their profile. This feature is designed to help people better differentiate between automated accounts &#8212; like bots that retweet the news, public service announcements or other updates &#8212; from those operated by humans. It&#8217;s not, however, designed to help users identify the &#8220;bad bots,&#8221; which are those that pose as people, often to spread misinformation or spam.<\/p>\n<p>The company has been contemplating labeling bots for years.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"RbxNRYWSCL\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/02\/3-guiding-principles-for-ceos-who-post-on-twitter\/\">3 guiding principles for CEOs who post on Twitter<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;3 guiding principles for CEOs who post on Twitter&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/02\/3-guiding-principles-for-ceos-who-post-on-twitter\/embed\/#?secret=RbxNRYWSCL\" data-secret=\"RbxNRYWSCL\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>In 2018, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/09\/05\/twitter-is-considering-badging-bots-as-far-as-we-can-detect-them\/\">Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey was asked<\/a> during a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing whether he believed users had a &#8220;right to know&#8221; if they were speaking to a bot or a human on Twitter&#8217;s platform. He agreed that Twitter should add more context to tweets and was considering identifying bots, to the extent that it could. However, Dorsey also pointed out it would be more difficult to identify bots that were using scripting to give the appearance of being a human, compared with those that were leveraging Twitter&#8217;s API.<\/p>\n<p>Last year, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/17\/twitter-verification-bots-2021\/\">finally solidified those plans<\/a>, saying it would later introduce new features that would allow users to be able to distinguish between human-run accounts and those that were automated. When Twitter <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/20\/twitter-opens-account-verification-applications-to-the-public-under-new-guidelines\/\">launched<\/a> its account verification system in May, it reminded users that it would soon offer other ways to identify different types of accounts beyond the long-coveted blue badge &#8212; such as labels for bots.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200570\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200570\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2200570\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=150,150 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=300,300 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=768,768 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=680,680 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=1536,1536 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=32,32 32w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=50,50 50w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=64,64 64w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=96,96 96w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0.png?resize=128,128 128w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200570\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Twitter<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Today, Twitter says its new &#8220;Automated Account&#8221; label that identifies &#8220;good bots&#8221; will be made available to over 500 Developer Accounts. This group will test the feature and provide feedback before it&#8217;s opened up more broadly to all Twitter developers. As it&#8217;s still a test for the time being, the label won&#8217;t be required.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>However, when Twitter <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/10\/twitter-rewrites-developer-policy-to-better-support-academic-research-and-use-of-good-bots\/\">updated its Developer Policy<\/a> last year, it did ask developers to indicate in their account profile or bio whether the account was a bot, what the account is and who&#8217;s behind it. These account labels would allow developers an easier way to comply with that policy rather than having to handwrite this information in their bio.<\/p>\n<p>Twitter tells TechCrunch that based on what it learns during this experiment, it may decide to make adopting the label a requirement for all developers who run automated accounts in the future, once it becomes broadly available.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200569\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200569\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2200569\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=150,150 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=300,300 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=768,768 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=680,680 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=1536,1536 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=32,32 32w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=50,50 50w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=64,64 64w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=96,96 96w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/pasted-image-0-1.png?resize=128,128 128w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200569\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Twitter<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>To be clear, Twitter doesn&#8217;t have any problem with those who run good bots, as it understands how automation can allow accounts to update people with helpful, relevant or, sometimes, just fun information. The company even celebrated a few of its favorite bots when announcing today&#8217;s developer news, including the public service account <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/earthquakesSF\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/twitter.com\/earthquakesSF&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1631302191562000&amp;usg=AFQjCNH5WDq6vi7Y7nVk5ty0x9z5Bg2PwA\">@earthquakesSF<\/a>; a bot offering COVID-19 updates, <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/vax_progress\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/twitter.com\/vax_progress&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1631302191562000&amp;usg=AFQjCNEYvakD6bj-U6vi7AnMeJNzkf0WuA\">@vax_progress<\/a>; a bot that offers an ongoing breakdown of the last 100 bills introduced in Congress, <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/last100bills\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/twitter.com\/last100bills&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1631302191562000&amp;usg=AFQjCNG5V_BHVBuBJqzqui6U6migBp8Elg\">@last100bills<\/a>; an accessibility-focused bot, <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/alttxtreminder\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/twitter.com\/alttxtreminder&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1631302191562000&amp;usg=AFQjCNHQy3thJB3m9OxdwEEf_Nbu4gbPvA\">@AltTxtReminder<\/a>; and others that just add value in their own way, like <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/met_drawings\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/twitter.com\/met_drawings&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1631302191562000&amp;usg=AFQjCNELU1MqaEpv-GENvi0GFP3oTDDFFA\">@met_drawings<\/a>, which shares public domain works from The Met\u2019s Drawings &amp; Prints department, or the goofy <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/EmojiMashupBot\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/twitter.com\/EmojiMashupBot&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1631302191562000&amp;usg=AFQjCNGchDl4BjnSSP1Pt0bbcP4ufPqh3A\">@EmojiMashupBot<\/a>, among others.<\/p>\n<p>All these will be a part of the initial test group.<\/p>\n<p>Twitter is also less concerned with how consumers may use automation to update their own accounts, perhaps by using third-party tools like IFTTT to post links or other content.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;You are ultimately responsible for the actions taken with your account, or by applications associated with your account,&#8221; Twitter&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/rules-and-policies\/twitter-automation\">policy<\/a> advises Twitter users. &#8220;Before authorizing a third-party application to access or use your account, make sure you&#8217;ve thoroughly investigated the application and understand what it will do.&#8221; It also adds that Twitter users that adopt automation will still need to adhere to Twitter&#8217;s guidelines.<\/p>\n<p>The company has been on a tear lately in terms of rolling out new features. Just this week, it has launched <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/twitter-communities\/\">Communities<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/twitter-users-in-turkey-can-now-emoji-react-to-tweets\/\">tests of emoji reactions<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/07\/twitter-full-width-image-tweets-test\/\">support for full-width photos and videos<\/a> and a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/twitter-tests-a-safety-feature-on-web-to-remove-followers-without-blocking-them\/\">way to &#8220;soft block&#8221; followers<\/a>, among other things.<\/p>\n<p>Twitter has not said how long the test would run before the Automated Account labels are rolled out more broadly.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Twitter today is introducing a new feature that will allow accounts to self-identify as bots by adding a label to their profile. This feature is designed to help people better differentiate between automated accounts &#8212; like bots that retweet the news, public service announcements or other updates &#8212; from those operated by humans. It&#8217;s not, and Jio delay their India smartphone launch"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The JioPhone Next, the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/06\/24\/google-and-jio-platforms-announce-worlds-cheapest-smartphone-jiophone-next\/\">much-awaited smartphone<\/a> designed by Google and India&#8217;s Jio Platforms to tap hundreds of millions of users in the world&#8217;s second-largest internet market, won&#8217;t launch on Friday, the Indian technology giant said Thursday midnight.<\/p>\n<p>In a statement issued just now, Jio Platforms said it has been testing the smartphone with a &#8220;limited set of users for further refinement&#8221; and is &#8220;actively working to make it available more widely&#8221; around the time of Diwali festival, which is scheduled for early November.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"9xPAAjv4Bq\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/06\/24\/google-and-jio-platforms-announce-worlds-cheapest-smartphone-jiophone-next\/\">Google and India&#8217;s Jio Platforms announce budget Android smartphone JioPhone Next<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Google and India&#8217;s Jio Platforms announce budget Android smartphone JioPhone Next&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/06\/24\/google-and-jio-platforms-announce-worlds-cheapest-smartphone-jiophone-next\/embed\/#?secret=9xPAAjv4Bq\" data-secret=\"9xPAAjv4Bq\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>The Indian firm, which operates the largest telecom network with over 400 million subscribers, blamed global semiconductor shortages for the launch delay and said it expects the additional two months &#8220;will&#8221; mitigate that.<\/p>\n<p>The JioPhone Next smartphone, unveiled in June this year, was scheduled to launch on Friday. Neither of the firms had given any indication in recent days that they may have to postpone the launch. &#8220;The companies remain committed to their vision of opening up new possibilities for millions of Indians, especially those who will experience the internet for the very first time,&#8221; the Indian firm said in a press statement.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2169666\" style=\"width: 1510px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2169666\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2169666 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/google-jiophone-next.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1500\" height=\"746\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/google-jiophone-next.jpg 1500w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/google-jiophone-next.jpg?resize=150,75 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/google-jiophone-next.jpg?resize=300,149 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/google-jiophone-next.jpg?resize=768,382 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/google-jiophone-next.jpg?resize=680,338 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/google-jiophone-next.jpg?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1500px) 100vw, 1500px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2169666\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Mukesh Ambani, India&#8217;s richest man and the chairman of Reliance Industries, which operates Jio Platforms, unveiling JioPhone Next at an event in June this year <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Jio Platforms<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Powered by &#8220;extremely optimized Android\u201d mobile operating system, the JioPhone Next phone is marketed to be an &#8220;ultra-affordable 4G smartphone&#8221; to tap the roughly 300 million users in India who are still on slower networks. The two firms have said that they plan to eventually launch the smartphone in other markets as well.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>At an event in June, the two firms said the JioPhone Next will\u00a0feature a \u201cfast, high-quality camera\u201d which will support HDR, and will be protected by the latest Android releases and security updates. It will also\u00a0ship with a range of features, including Read Aloud and Translate Now that will work with any text on the phone screen, including web pages, apps, messages and even photos, the two firms have said.<\/p>\n<p>Analysts have said in recent weeks that the JioPhone Next &#8212; whose price and tech specifications are yet to be revealed &#8212; could disrupt the Indian smartphone market &#8212; the world&#8217;s second largest &#8212; and help the telecom network further solidify its dominance in the country.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;At present, there are 430 million smartphone users, 115 million JioPhone users [Jio&#8217;s &#8220;smart&#8221; featurephone] and 320 million featurephone (2G) users in India. We believe smartphone users with devices priced above $100 are unlikely to opt for a sub $100 device,&#8221; analysts at Jefferies wrote in a report to clients this week. &#8220;That leaves 25% of smartphone users, i.e. 105 million smartphones, 115 million JioPhone users and 320 million featurephone users as the addressable market for JioPhone Next. Assuming replacement cycle of 2 years for smartphones and 3 years for JioPhone\/featurephones, the addressable market for JioPhone Next could be 200m devices annually.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The smartphone is the latest collaboration between the two firms. Last year, Google invested <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/15\/google-invests-4-5-billion-in-indias-reliance-jio-platforms\/\">$4.5 billion in Jio Platforms<\/a> and that&#8217;s where it first announced the plans to develop cheap smartphones with the Indian telecom operator. Facebook and scores of other firms have also bought stakes in the Indian firm. Jio Platforms operates a number of businesses, including telecom giant Jio Infocomm, which competes with Airtel and Vodafone Idea; and e-commerce firm JioMart, which competes with Tata-owned BigBasket, SoftBank-backed Grofers and Amazon and Walmart&#8217;s Flipkart.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The JioPhone Next, the much-awaited smartphone designed by Google and India&#8217;s Jio Platforms to tap hundreds of millions of users in the world&#8217;s second-largest internet market, won&#8217;t launch on Friday, the Indian technology giant said Thursday midnight. In a statement issued just now, Jio Platforms said it has been testing the smartphone with a &#8220;limited style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/amitvedand\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tAmit Anand is a founding partner of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.jungle.vc\/\">Jungle Ventures<\/a> and an early pioneer and leader in the development of Southeast Asia\u2019s venture capital industry.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Southeast Asian tech<\/span> companies are drawing the attention of investors around the world. In 2020, startups in the region raised over $8.2 billion, about four times more than they did in 2015. This trend continued in 2021, with regional M&amp;A hitting a record high of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/world\/asia-pacific\/asia-ma-bonanza-fuelled-by-southeast-asia-private-equity-deals-2021-07-01\/\">$124.8 billion<\/a> in the first half of 2021, up 83% from a year earlier.<\/p>\n<p>This begs the question: Who exactly is investing in Southeast Asia?<\/p>\n<p>Let\u2019s explore the three key types of investors pouring money into and driving the growth of Southeast Asia\u2019s tech ecosystem.<\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--right\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tOver 229 family offices have been registered in Singapore since 2020, with total assets under management of an estimated $20 billion.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<h2>Big tech<\/h2>\n<p>Southeast Asia has become an attractive market for U.S. and Chinese tech firms. Internet penetration here stands at 70%, higher than the global average, and digital adoption in the region remains nascent \u2014 it wasn&#8217;t until the pandemic that adoption of digital services such as e-wallets and online shopping took off.<\/p>\n<p>China\u2019s tech giants Tencent and Alibaba were among the first to support early e-commerce growth in Southeast Asia with investments in Sea Limited and Lazada, and have since expanded their footprint into other internet verticals. Alibaba has backed Akulaku, M-Pay (eMonkey), DANA, Wave Money and Mynt (GCash), while Tencent has invested in Voyager Innovations (PayMaya), SHAREit, iflix, Ookbee and Sanook.<\/p>\n<p>U.S. tech firms have also recently entered the scene. In June 2020, Gojek closed a $3 billion Series F round from Google, Facebook, Tencent and Visa. Google, together with Singapore\u2019s Temasek Holdings, invested some $350 million in Tokopedia in October. Meanwhile, Microsoft invested an undisclosed amount in Grab in 2018 and has invested $100 million in Indonesian e-commerce firm Bukalapak.<\/p>\n<h2>Venture capitalists<\/h2>\n<p>In Q1 2021, Southeast Asian startups raised $6 billion, according to DealStreetAsia, positioning 2021 as another record year for VC investment in the region.<\/p>\n<p>The region is also rising in prominence as a destination for investment capital relative to the rest of Asia. Regional VC investment grew 5.2 times to $8.2 billion in 2020 from $1.6 billion in 2015, as we can see in the table below.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200087\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200087\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2200087\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/1.-Venture-Capital-Investment-per-Region.jpg\" alt=\"Venture capital investment by region 2015-2020\" width=\"1024\" height=\"384\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/1.-Venture-Capital-Investment-per-Region.jpg 1132w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/1.-Venture-Capital-Investment-per-Region.jpg?resize=150,56 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/1.-Venture-Capital-Investment-per-Region.jpg?resize=300,112 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/1.-Venture-Capital-Investment-per-Region.jpg?resize=768,288 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/1.-Venture-Capital-Investment-per-Region.jpg?resize=680,255 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/1.-Venture-Capital-Investment-per-Region.jpg?resize=50,19 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200087\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Jungle VC<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Southeast Asia also has many opportunities for VC investment relative to its market size. From 2015 to 2020, China saw VC investment of nearly $300 per person; for Southeast Asia \u2014 despite a recent investment boom \u2014 this metric sits at just $47.50 per person, or just a sixth of that in China. This implies a substantial opportunity for investments to develop the region\u2019s digital economy.<\/p>\n<p>The region\u2019s rising population and growth prospects are higher due to China\u2019s population growth challenges, alongside the latter\u2019s higher digital economy market saturation and maturity.<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Southeast Asian tech companies are drawing the attention of investors around the world. In 2020, startups in the region raised over $8.2 billion, about four times more than they did in Southeast Asia &amp; Oceania","slug":"ec-southeast-asia-oceania","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576908510"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576908510"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576908510"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576908510"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576908510"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":81819,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/facebook\/","name":"Facebook","slug":"facebook","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/81819"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81819"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":23409740,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ggv-capital\/","name":"ggv capital","slug":"ggv-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/23409740"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=23409740"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=23409740"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=23409740"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=23409740"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[{"id":576796356,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/extracrunch\/market-analysis\/","name":"Market Analysis","slug":"market-analysis","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2200492,"date":"2021-09-09T12:29:15","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T19:29:15","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200492"},"modified":"2021-09-09T15:25:35","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T22:25:35","slug":"box-wins-proxy-board-battle-with-activist-investor-starboard-value","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/box-wins-proxy-board-battle-with-activist-investor-starboard-value\/","title":{"rendered":"Box wins proxy board battle with activist investor Starboard Value"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">A battle between <a href=\"http:\/\/box.com\">Box<\/a> and its majority shareholder <a href=\"https:\/\/www.starboardvalue.com\/\">Starboard Value<\/a> over control of the board ended today when the company&#8217;s slate of directors easily defeated Starboard&#8217;s. It culminated months of maneuvering on both sides as they battled for control of the company.<\/p>\n<p>Box, in <a href=\"https:\/\/www.boxinvestorrelations.com\/news-and-media\/news\/press-release-details\/2021\/Stockholders-Re-Elect-All-Box-Director-Nominees-at-2021-Annual-Meeting\/default.aspx\">a somewhat generic statement<\/a>, expressed gratitude for the results:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>Box appreciates the support and perspectives we have received from our stockholders throughout this process. The Board and management team will remain focused on continuing to transform Box and executing Box\u2019s strategy to grow profitably and deliver significant value to all Box stockholders.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Starboard on the other hand, as you might expect, was unhappy with the outcome and didn&#8217;t hide that in <a href=\"https:\/\/www.streetinsider.com\/Board+Changes\/Starboard+Delivers+Open+Letter+To+Box+%28BOX%29+Stockholders\/18922324.html\">a letter to shareholders<\/a> released earlier today.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We are certainly disappointed by the results of this election, which were heavily skewed by the voting rights tied to the preferred equity financing and the use of stockholder capital to aggressively repurchase shares ahead of the record date from stockholders likely to support change. At this juncture, the future of Box is in the Board&#8217;s hands, and there is a significant amount of work left to be done. Many commitments have been made, and we hope that Box will finally be able to follow through on its promises to drive improved results, accountability, governance, and compensation practices,&#8221; managing director Peter A. Feld wrote in the letter.<\/p>\n<p>This all began when Starboard Value invested in Box, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/09\/03\/starboard-value-takes-7-5-stake-in-box\/\">taking a 7.5% stake<\/a>, which would eventually grow to 8.8% in the company. With that stake, it became one of the largest shareholder, but it remained relatively quiet until March of this year. That is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/03\/as-activist-investors-loom-whats-next-for-box\/\">when public rumblings began<\/a> that Starboard was unhappy with the direction of the company, a conflict that could have ultimately resulted in the ouster of founder and CEO Aaron Levie or the sale of Box.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"OTuvgbcbmB\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/09\/03\/starboard-value-takes-7-5-stake-in-box\/\">Starboard Value takes 7.5% stake in Box<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Starboard Value takes 7.5% stake in Box&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/09\/03\/starboard-value-takes-7-5-stake-in-box\/embed\/#?secret=OTuvgbcbmB\" data-secret=\"OTuvgbcbmB\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>The situation took an interesting turn when Box announced it was taking <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/04\/08\/kkr-hands-box-a-500m-lifeline\/\">a $500 million investment from KKR,<\/a> a move that Starboard took great exception to and made clear <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/04\/starboard-value-puts-box-on-notice-that-its-looking-to-take-over-board\/\">in a letter published<\/a> at the beginning of May that it wanted significant changes to take place. As <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/04\/starboard-value-puts-box-on-notice-that-its-looking-to-take-over-board\/\">we wrote at the time<\/a>:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>While they couched the letter in mostly polite language, it\u2019s quite clear Starboard is exasperated with Box. \u201cWhile we appreciate the dialogue we have had with Box\u2019s management team and Board of Directors (the \u201cBoard\u201d) over the past two years, we have grown increasingly frustrated with continued poor results, questionable capital allocation decisions, and subpar shareholder returns,\u201d Starboard wrote in its letter.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Less than a week later Starboard <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/10\/activist-investor-starboard-value-makes-official-bid-for-box-board-seats-in-letter\/\">made a move for board seats<\/a> and the battle was on for control. Box&#8217;s position was strengthened <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/27\/box-beats-expectations-raises-guidance-as-it-looks-for-a-comeback\/\">by two decent earnings reports<\/a> prior to the vote; the company took the unusual move <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/12\/box-reports-earnings-early-to-give-shareholders-time-to-review-financials-ahead-of-board-vote\/\">of delivering the results early<\/a> in order to give the voters that information prior to the vote.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The company also made the unusual move of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/06\/box-takes-fight-with-activist-investor-public-in-sec-filing\/\">filing a document with the SEC<\/a> that pushed back against Starboard&#8217;s slate of candidates. In the end, Box won the battle. Alan Pelz-Sharpe, founder and principal analyst at Deep Analysis, who has been watching the content management space where Box operates for years, sees this as a victory for Levie and Box.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;It was not a surprise to me that Box won the day. In my opinion, Starboard misread and underestimated the loyalty that Aaron Levie generates. The fact is that to most Box employees and investors, the company is a success story, and they also know that the customer base is pretty engaged and that there is plenty of room for future growth,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;For Box this vote of confidence will mean that they can (if they want) make some acquisitions and invest more in R&amp;D moving forward, without constantly having an aggressive investor looking over their shoulder,&#8221; Pelz-Sharpe added.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s hard to know what happens next, but Starboard still maintains its shares for now, and it still has some clout in those numbers. Throughout its ownership tenure, Box has performed better, as the recent earnings results have shown, and the firm says that this remains the ultimate goal.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;As we have repeatedly stated, our only goal has been to help Box perform better and adopt best-in-class practices across operating performance, financial results, governance and compensation in order to create long-term value for the benefit of all stockholders. We will continue to monitor progress at Box, and we hope to see the company embrace the changes catalyzed by our involvement and create long-term value,&#8221; Starboard&#8217;s Feld wrote.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"rqKxNO4koA\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/06\/box-takes-fight-with-activist-investor-public-in-sec-filing\/\">Box takes fight with activist investor public in SEC filing<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Box takes fight with activist investor public in SEC filing&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/06\/box-takes-fight-with-activist-investor-public-in-sec-filing\/embed\/#?secret=rqKxNO4koA\" data-secret=\"rqKxNO4koA\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>A battle between Box and its majority shareholder Starboard Value over control of the board ended today when the company&#8217;s slate of directors easily defeated Starboard&#8217;s. It culminated months of maneuvering on both sides as they battled for control of the company. Box, in a somewhat generic statement, expressed gratitude for the results: Box appreciates [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":521068,"featured_media":1877985,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"524e5462-f7a0-3620-bfd0-6af348002d39"},"categories":[24405894,449557052,449557044,17396],"tags":[16461990,426319975,53395,576608073,576695477],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3yVpbIt","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","editorialContentProvider":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[983141],"hide_featured_image":false,"canonical_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/box-wins-proxy-board-battle-with-activist-investor-starboard-value\/","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200492"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2200492"}],"version-history":[{"count":10,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200492\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2200638,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2200492\/revisions\/2200638"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/guest-authors\/ronjourn"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2200492&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1 Enterprise Journey with Aaron Levie (Box)DSC00198"},"author":5302483,"license":{"source_key":"other","source":"TechCrunch"},"authors":[5302483],"caption":{"rendered":"<p>Box\u2019s Enterprise Journey with Aaron Levie BoxDSC00198<\/p>\n"},"alt_text":"Box\u2019s Enterprise Journey with Aaron Levie BoxDSC00198","media_type":"image","mime_type":"image\/jpeg","media_details":{"width":6000,"height":4000,"file":"2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg","sizes":{"thumbnail":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=150,100","width":150,"height":100,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=150"},"medium":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=300,200","width":300,"height":200,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=300"},"medium_large":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=768,512","width":768,"height":512,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=1024"},"large":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=680,453","width":680,"height":453,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=680"},"1536x1536":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=1536,1024","width":1536,"height":1024,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=1536"},"2048x2048":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=2048,1365","width":2048,"height":1365,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=2048"},"guest-author-32":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=32,32","width":32,"height":32,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=32&h=32&crop=1"},"guest-author-50":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=50,50","width":50,"height":50,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=50&h=50&crop=1"},"guest-author-64":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=64,64","width":64,"height":64,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=64&h=64&crop=1"},"guest-author-96":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=96,96","width":96,"height":96,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=96&h=96&crop=1"},"guest-author-128":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=128,128","width":128,"height":128,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=128&h=128&crop=1"},"concierge-thumb":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?resize=50,33","width":50,"height":33,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg?w=50"},"full":{"file":"Box\u2019s-Enterprise-Journey-with-Aaron-Levie-BoxDSC00198.jpg","width":1024,"height":683,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2019\/09\/Box\u2 el}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":16461990,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/aaron-levie\/","name":"Aaron Levie","slug":"aaron-levie","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/16461990"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=16461990"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=16461990"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=16461990"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=16461990"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":426319975,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/activist-investors\/","name":"activist investors","slug":"activist-investors","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/426319975"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=426319975"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=426319975"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=426319975"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=426319975"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":53395,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/box\/","name":"Box","slug":"box","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/53395"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=53395"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=53395"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=53395"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=53395"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576608073,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/cloud-content-management\/","name":"cloud content management","slug":"cloud-content-management","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576608073"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576608073"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576608073"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576608073"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576608073"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576695477,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/starboard-value\/","name":"Starboard Value","slug":"starboard-value","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576695477"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576695477"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576695477"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576695477"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576695477"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200062,"date":"2021-09-09T11:59:03","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T18:59:03","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200062"},"modified":"2021-09-09T12:24:56","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T19:24:56","slug":"epic-games-to-shut-down-houseparty-in-october-including-the-video-chat-fortnite-mode-feature","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/epic-games-to-shut-down-houseparty-in-october-including-the-video-chat-fortnite-mode-feature\/","title":{"rendered":"Epic Games to shut down Houseparty in October, including the video chat &#8216;Fortnite Mode&#8217; feature"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Houseparty, the social video chat app <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/06\/12\/fortnite-maker-epic-acquires-social-video-app-houseparty\/\">acquired<\/a> by Fortnite maker Epic Games <a href=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/epic-games-paid-35-million-for-houseparty-in-2019-2020-5\">for a reported $35 million<\/a> back in 2019, is shutting down. The company <a href=\"https:\/\/houseparty.com\/blog\/saying-goodbye-to-houseparty\/\">says<\/a> Houseparty will be discontinued in October when the app will stop functioning for its existing users; it will be pulled from the app stores today, however. Related to this move, Epic Games&#8217; &#8220;<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/18\/houseparty-adds-fortnite-mode-bringing-video-chat-to-the-popular-game\/\">Fortnite Mode&#8221; feature<\/a>, which leveraged Houseparty to bring video chat to Fortnite gamers, will also be discontinued.<\/p>\n<p>Founded in 2015, Houseparty offered a way for users to participate in group video chats with friends and even play games, like Uno, trivia, Heads Up and others. Last year, Epic Games <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/18\/houseparty-adds-fortnite-mode-bringing-video-chat-to-the-popular-game\/\">integrated<\/a> Houseparty with Fortnite, initially to allow gamers to see live feeds from friends while gaming, then later <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/04\/05\/fortnite-users-can-now-live-stream-gameplay-to-housepartys-social-video-app\/\">adding support<\/a> to livestream gameplay directly into Houseparty. At the time, these integrations appeared to be the end goal that explained why Epic Games had bought the social startup in the first place.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"tHhmV96iAI\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/05\/8-investors-discuss-social-gamings-biggest-opportunities\/\">8 investors discuss social gaming&#8217;s biggest opportunities<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;8 investors discuss social gaming&#8217;s biggest opportunities&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/05\/8-investors-discuss-social-gamings-biggest-opportunities\/embed\/#?secret=tHhmV96iAI\" data-secret=\"tHhmV96iAI\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Now, just over two years after the acquisition was announced, and less than half a year since <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/04\/05\/fortnite-users-can-now-live-stream-gameplay-to-housepartys-social-video-app\/\">support for livestreaming<\/a> was added to the app, Houseparty is shutting down.<\/p>\n<p>The company didn&#8217;t offer any solid insight into what, at first glance, feels like an admission of failure to capitalize on its acquisition. But the reality is that Epic Games may have something larger in store beyond just video chat. That said, all Epic Games would say today is that the Houseparty team could no longer give the app the attention it required &#8212; a statement that indicates an executive decision to shift the team&#8217;s focus to other matters.<\/p>\n<p>While none of the Houseparty team members are being let go as a result of this move, we&#8217;re told, they will be joining other teams where they will work on new ways to allow for &#8220;social interactions&#8221; across the Epic Games family of products. The company&#8217;s announcement hinted that those social features would be designed and built at the &#8220;metaverse scale.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The &#8220;metaverse&#8221; is an increasingly used buzzword that references a shared virtual environment, like those provided by large-scale online gaming platforms such as Fortnite, Roblox and others. Facebook, too, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/28\/zuckerberg-is-turning-trillion-dollar-facebook-into-a-metaverse-company-he-tells-investors\/\">claims the metaverse<\/a> is the next big gambit for social networking, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg having described it as an &#8220;embodied internet that you&#8217;re inside of rather than just looking at.&#8221;<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>To some extent, Fortnite has begun to embrace the metaverse by offering non-gaming experiences like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/24\/fortnite-hosted-a-psychedelic-travis-scott-concert-and-12-3m-people-watched\/\">online<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/09\/fortnite-ariana-grande-concert-metaverse\/\">concerts<\/a> you attend as your avatar, and other live events. Ahead of its shutdown, Houseparty also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/13\/houseparty-expands-beyond-video-chat-with-co-watching-of-live-events\/\">toyed with live events<\/a> that users would co-watch and participate in alongside their friends.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">3\/6 The metaverse vision and products we\u2019re working on at <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/EpicGames?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@EpicGames<\/a> are also about shared experiences, but in a more rich form than 2D video &#8212; one that&#39;s better positioned to shape the next generation of the internet.<\/p>\n<p>&mdash; sima sistani (@SimaSistani) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/SimaSistani\/status\/1436045438830972930?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 9, 2021<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>An Epic Games spokesperson tells TechCrunch the Houseparty team has worked on (and continues to work on) a number of other projects that focus on social. But some of the &#8220;multiple, larger projects&#8221; Epic Games has in the works remain undisclosed, we&#8217;re told.<\/p>\n<p>In terms of social products, Houseparty&#8217;s technology now underpins all of Fortnite voice chat and the features they built are widely available for free to developers through <a href=\"https:\/\/www.epicgames.com\/site\/en-US\/news\/epic-online-services-launches-free-in-game-voice-and-easy-anti-cheat\">Epic Games Services<\/a>. They also worked on building out new social experiences, which have ranged from the social RSVP functions for Fortnite&#8217;s global events, like the recent Ariana Grande concert, to the upcoming <a href=\"https:\/\/www.epicgames.com\/fortnite\/en-US\/news\/prepare-for-the-end-of-chapter-2-season-7-in-the-finale-event-operation-sky-fire\">&#8220;Operation: Sky Fire&#8221; event<\/a> for collaborating quests and other game mechanics. More social functionality and new experiences are also being built into Fortnite&#8217;s user-generated content platform, Create Mode.<\/p>\n<p>While it may seem odd to close an app that only last year experienced a boost in usage due to the pandemic, it appears the COVID bump didn&#8217;t have staying power.<\/p>\n<p>At the height of lockdowns, Houseparty had <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/15\/houseparty-reports-50m-sign-ups-in-past-month-amid-covid-19-lockdowns\/\">reported it had gained 50 million new sign-ups<\/a> in a month&#8217;s time as users looked to video apps to connect with family and friends while the world was shut down. But as the pandemic wore on, other video chat experiences gained more ground. Zoom, which had established itself as an essential tool for remote work, became a tool for<a href=\"https:\/\/www.nbcnews.com\/think\/opinion\/covid-s-remote-parties-allowed-us-celebrate-all-our-dearest-ncna1263552\"> hanging out with friends<\/a> after-hours, as well. Facebook also started to eat Houseparty&#8217;s lunch with <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/24\/faceboo-launches-drop-in-video-chat-rooms-to-rival-houseparty\/\">its debut of drop-in video chat &#8220;Rooms&#8221; last year,<\/a> which offered a similar group video experience. And bored users shifted to audio-based social networking on <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/18\/clubhouse-app-chat-rooms\/\">apps like Clubhouse<\/a> or Twitter Spaces.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2200392\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2200392\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2200392\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Houseparty-quarterly-downloads.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"481\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Houseparty-quarterly-downloads.png 1150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Houseparty-quarterly-downloads.png?resize=150,106 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Houseparty-quarterly-downloads.png?resize=300,212 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Houseparty-quarterly-downloads.png?resize=768,543 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Houseparty-quarterly-downloads.png?resize=680,481 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/Houseparty-quarterly-downloads.png?resize=50,35 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2200392\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Apptopia<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>According to data from <a href=\"https:\/\/apptopia.com\/\">Apptopia<\/a>, Houseparty has been continually declining since the pandemic bump. To date, its app has seen a total of 111 million downloads across iOS and Android, with the majority (63 million) on iOS. The U.S. was Houseparty&#8217;s largest market, accounting for 43.4% of downloads, followed by the U.K. (9.8%), then Germany (5.6%).<\/p>\n<p>Epic Games, meanwhile, said the app served &#8220;tens of millions&#8221; of users worldwide. It insists the closure wasn&#8217;t decided lightly, nor was the decision to shutter &#8220;Fortnite Mode&#8221; made due to lack of adoption.<\/p>\n<p>Houseparty will alert users to the shutdown via in-app notifications ahead of its final closure in October. At that point, Fortnite Mode will also no longer be available.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Houseparty, the social video chat app acquired by Fortnite maker Epic Games for a reported $35 million back in 2019, is shutting down. The company says Houseparty will be discontinued in October when the app will stop functioning for its existing users; it will be pulled from the app stores today, however. Zuckerberg","slug":"mark-zuckerberg","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/341024"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=341024"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=341024"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=341024"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=341024"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576603748,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/metaverse\/","name":"metaverse","slug":"metaverse","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576603748"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576603748"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576603748"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576603748"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576603748"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":11386,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/online-games\/","name":"online games","slug":"online-games","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/11386"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=11386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=11386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=11386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=11386"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200225,"date":"2021-09-09T11:57:55","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T18:57:55","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200225"},"modified":"2021-09-09T12:58:42","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T19:58:42","slug":"some-of-the-biggest-names-in-private-equity-think-this-go-go-market-has-another-year-or-two-at-least","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/some-of-the-biggest-names-in-private-equity-think-this-go-go-market-has-another-year-or-two-at-least\/","title":{"rendered":"Some of the biggest names in private equity think this go-go market has another year or two (at least)"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Earlier today, as part of a private event, this editor was afforded the opportunity to talk with some of the biggest names in the world of private equity, including Carlyle co-founder David Rubenstein; Bain Capital co-chair Steve Pagliuca; Jean Salata, the CEO and founding partner of Baring Private Equity Asia; and Sheila Patel, the vice chairman of B Capital Group AGM and formerly the chair of Goldman Sachs Asset Management.<\/p>\n<p>We covered a lot of ground, from how interested Carlyle and the other firms are in blockchain technologies (the feedback here was a little mixed), to how focused they are on sustainable and socially responsible investing. On this front, Rubenstein claimed that &#8220;private equity people are very focused on it,&#8221; and predicted that when a financial metric emerges to better assess companies on this front &#8220;within the next five years,&#8221; it will become a routine factor in evaluating companies.<\/p>\n<p>Patel &#8212; who previously served on Goldman&#8217;s inclusion and diversity committee &#8212; agreed, noting upward of one-third of investors right now find it impossible to measure so-called <a href=\"https:\/\/www.investopedia.com\/terms\/e\/environmental-social-and-governance-esg-criteria.asp\">ESG <\/a>criteria (though she expects this to change quickly).<\/p>\n<p>Naturally, too, we discussed the current market, including how the investors differentiate their firms&#8217; offerings when everyone these days has a money cannon &#8212; and how long they expect to be operating at hyperspeed. In feedback that might surprise some readers and will seem obvious to others, the PE execs suggested that this go-go market could easily continue into 2023, if not beyond.<\/p>\n<p>Only attendees of the event will have access to the full interview, but some notes from this last part of our discussion follow:<\/p>\n<h3><strong>Steve<\/strong> Pagliuca:<\/h3>\n<p>[P]art of the reason we&#8217;re doing so well has been massive government intervention, which I think was warranted. As that starts to wane, we may see an effect from that. The unemployment rate right now is just over 5.2%, which is, to me, astounding in the middle of a pandemic, and it looks like there are lots of jobs out there still unfilled. Part of that is because the [government] payments came out, and less workers were looking for work, so we might see unemployment continue to go down as those payments stop, and the impact of that is going to be a key issue.<\/p>\n<h3><strong>David<\/strong> Rubenstein:<\/h3>\n<p>They say this is the best of times and the worst of times. It&#8217;s the best of times for investors, because if you&#8217;re in the tech world, if you&#8217;re in the investing world and you&#8217;re investing in India, China and the United States, you&#8217;ve made a lot of money and you&#8217;re beginning to think you&#8217;re a genius because you made so much money, and you just don&#8217;t realize that it&#8217;s the worst of times for people that don&#8217;t have internet access, [or who] work with their hands and not with their minds as much, [or who] aren&#8217;t educated [or] have childcare [needs]. Really, in the United States and probably other parts of the world, we are further and further creating [an] economic divide unfortunately and greater income inequality and a lack of social mobility, and that&#8217;s a real problem.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>For those for whom it&#8217;s been the best of times, eventually something will end. At some point, the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates &#8212;\u00a0 probably not until 2023, but maybe before &#8212; and at some point, people begin to say, &#8220;I&#8217;m taking more of my chips off the table. I&#8217;m not going to invest as much at these valuations.&#8221; I just got off a call this morning [regarding] a small deal in Asia where people want to pay things like 25 times projected revenues.<\/p>\n<h3><strong> Jean<\/strong> Salata:<\/h3>\n<p>You cannot separate the context of where we are with interest rates from where valuations are. At some point, interest rates are going to go up, but at the moment, what we have is a Fed that has bought something like $4 trillion worth of bonds over the last 18 months. I think right now, $120 billion a month is going into the system, which is depressing rates. [Meanwhile] people need to find a home for their investments to generate some kind of return, [meaning] pension funds, endowments, individual investors.<\/p>\n<p>If you look at valuations today, they&#8217;re probably in the 99th percentile or near the peak as far as multiples go. But if you look at them relative to the rates and earnings yield, less the say the 10-year [Treasury] rate, I think that&#8217;s probably only in the 20th or the 30th percentile &#8212;\u00a0 it&#8217;s something like that. And as I look back to 1999 and 2000, which I lived through and barely survived, the difference today is that although valuations are similar in terms of the frothiness, in terms of multiples, [that] interest rates back then were about 5% or 6%, and today, they&#8217;re 1%. That is a big difference.<\/p>\n<p>There are also structural things going on, and it comes back to this point about income inequality, which is a big issue everywhere in the world, including in China, by the way, and is self-perpetuating. People with financial assets are benefiting from what&#8217;s going on with [the Federal Reserve&#8217;s bond purchases]. Valuations are rising, and then the people who have all that money save more, so savings rates are going up, and as you save more because you don&#8217;t need to spend that much money, [that cycle] depresses rates even further. [So] I believe that even when the Fed starts to taper off and starts reducing [how much it&#8217;s spending on bonds], you&#8217;ll see rates staying lower than they have been in the past, which could support higher valuations levels for quite some time.<\/p>\n<h3><strong>Steve<\/strong> Pagliuca:<\/h3>\n<p>If you look at the ballooning national debt, if you applied a 5.5% interest rate to that, the interest that the government would be paying would be close to half the budget. So I just don&#8217;t see the politicians saying, &#8220;We&#8217;re going to [raise interest] rates really high.&#8221; Instead, they&#8217;re going to keep them down as long as they can, because the taxes will go up enormously if rates go back to historic [levels]. They can handle the spending because rates are so low, so you&#8217;re going to [continue to] see low interest rate trends, which props up these valuations.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Earlier today, as part of a private event, this editor was afforded the opportunity to talk with some of the biggest names in the world of private equity, including Carlyle co-founder David Rubenstein; Bain Capital co-chair Steve Pagliuca; Jean Salata, the CEO and founding partner of Baring Private Equity Asia; and Sheila Patel, the vice Equity","slug":"private-equity","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/29172"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=29172"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=29172"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=29172"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=29172"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":202,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/venture-capital\/","name":"venture capital","slug":"venture-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/202"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=202"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200453,"date":"2021-09-09T11:11:28","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T18:11:28","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200453"},"modified":"2021-09-09T11:59:26","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T18:59:26","slug":"sustainable-jet-fuel-company-alder-fuels-seals-investments-from-united-honeywell","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/sustainable-jet-fuel-company-alder-fuels-seals-investments-from-united-honeywell\/","title":{"rendered":"Sustainable jet fuel company Alder Fuels seals investments from United, Honeywell"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The aviation industry is notoriously difficult to decarbonize, in part because airplanes use a petroleum-based fuel to fly.<\/p>\n<p>Alder Fuels wants to change that. The new clean tech company, headed by Bryan Sherbacow, is developing a low-carbon jet fuel that can be used as a 100% drop-in replacement for petroleum fuel, without needing to adapt existing aircraft or engines. That&#8217;s notable because the only commercially available sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) still requires a 50-50 blend with conventional fuel.<\/p>\n<p>The technology has piqued the interest of the aviation industry. Alder Fuels said Thursday it has inked a multimillion dollar investment from aviation giants United and Honeywell \u2014 as well as a purchase agreement from United for 1.5 billion gallons of fuel, the largest known agreement for SAF in aviation history.<\/p>\n<p>United consumes around 4 billion gallons of fuel per year, a company spokesperson told TechCrunch, so the purchase agreement would account for nearly 40% of the airline&#8217;s overall annual fuel consumption.<\/p>\n<p>Before the fuel starts powering United airplanes, it must meet specifications outlined by ASTM International, an international organization that sets the standards for a wide range of materials and products. From there, Alder and Honeywell expect to commercialize the technology by 2025.<\/p>\n<p>Alder Fuels was formally launched earlier this year, but Sherbacow has been assessing the technology for around five years, he said in a recent interview with TechCrunch. It became clear through his previous work that the technology behind the low-carbon fuel \u2014 and especially the raw materials \u2014 needed to be scalable and widely available.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWhat we&#8217;re all looking for is [ \u2026 ] how do you access these carbon oil precursors and efficiently convert them into something that works within the existing refining infrastructure?\u201d Sherbacow said.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>To solve that problem, he\u2019s turned to carbon-rich woody biomass, like agricultural waste, which is turned into crude oil that can be used to make aviation fuel. The company uses a pyrolysis-based technology that transforms the biomass into a liquid and treats it in such a way that it can be put into existing refineries. Alder Fuels will initially use Honeywell\u2019s proprietary \u201cEcofining\u201d hydroprocessing technology. The ultimate aim is to make the new fuel compatible with all refining assets.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThere&#8217;s significant amount of [woody biomass] that&#8217;s already industrially aggregated but has either no or very low economic value today,\u201d Sherbacow explained. \u201cBut it\u2019s a great opportunity for us because it&#8217;s a store of carbon that we can utilize.\u201d It could even open up new markets for companies in forestry, agriculture and even the paper industry, which are already generating plenty of biowaste.<\/p>\n<p>Alder Fuels&#8217; research is supported by the U.S. Defense Logistics Agency and the Department of Energy, and Sherbacow stressed the importance of public-private partnerships to decarbonizing the aviation industry. Climate change has been of particular interest to President Joe Biden\u2019s administration, and incentives for sustainable aviation fuel will likely end up in the $3.5 trillion spending bill currently being debated by Congress.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThat&#8217;s one of the roles of government \u2026 to help the transition,\u201d he said. \u201cYou need to incentivize the incumbents to change their behavior, or they&#8217;re going to resist a disruptive change.\u201d<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The aviation industry is notoriously difficult to decarbonize, in part because airplanes use a petroleum-based fuel to fly. Alder Fuels wants to change that. The new clean tech company, headed by Bryan Sherbacow, is developing a low-carbon jet fuel that can be used as a 100% drop-in replacement for petroleum fuel, without needing to adapt
