fuel","slug":"sustainable-aviation-fuel","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576887827"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576887827"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576887827"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576887827"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576887827"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":38469,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/united\/","name":"United","slug":"united","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/38469"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=38469"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=38469"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=38469"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=38469"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200226,"date":"2021-09-09T11:06:28","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T18:06:28","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200226"},"modified":"2021-09-09T11:11:14","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T18:11:14","slug":"gm-extends-chevy-bolt-ev-production-shutdown-another-two-weeks","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/gm-extends-chevy-bolt-ev-production-shutdown-another-two-weeks\/","title":{"rendered":"GM extends Chevy Bolt EV production shutdown another two weeks"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">GM has extended a shutdown at its Orion Assembly Plant another two weeks due to a battery pack shortage related to the widespread Chevrolet Bolt EV and Bolt EUV safety recall.<\/p>\n<p>GM said the extended downtime at the Orion plant will last through September 20. Orion Assembly Plant in Michigan has been shut down since August 23.<\/p>\n<p>The recall, which now includes all Chevy Bolt EV and EUV models made since 2017, was issued after the automaker discovered two manufacturing defects in the battery cell that could increase the risk of fire. The possible fire risk prompted GM to recommend Bolt owners set the vehicle to a 90% state of charge limitation and avoid depleting the battery below 70 miles of range. The National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/14\/nhtsa-urges-some-chevy-bolt-owners-to-park-their-car-away-from-home-citing-fire-risk\/\">recommends<\/a> Bolt drivers park their vehicles away from their homes to reduce fire risk.<\/p>\n<p>The automaker said it is working with its supplier LG Chem to &#8220;update manufacturing processes.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Orion was initially shuttered in August because of a shortage of semiconductor chips. GM later notified employees that the plant would continue to be down because of a shortage of batteries related to the recall.<\/p>\n<p>The recall is expected to cost GM $1.8 billion. A GM spokesperson did not provide an update on whether this extended downtime would push that number higher. The automaker has said it will seek reimbursement from LG Chem.<\/p>\n<h2>Chip shortages<\/h2>\n<p>While the global shortage of semiconductor chips has persisted, GM said it will be able to resume production at several of its plants over the next two weeks.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Full production will begin at its Fort Wayne Assembly and Silao Assembly plants, which produces the Chevrolet Silverado 1500 and GMC Sierra 1500 models, beginning September 13 after being briefly impacted by the global semiconductor shortage, GM said.<\/p>\n<p>All of GM\u2019s full-size truck and full-size SUV plants in North American will be running full production next week.<\/p>\n<p>GM&#8217;s Spring Hill Assembly plant in Tennessee will resume production of the GMC Acadia and Cadillac XT5 and XT6 on September 20, after being shuttered since mid-July. That plant will be shut down again as part of a previously scheduled extended downtime beginning the week of September 27 through the week of November 22 for new-model tooling installation.<\/p>\n<p>Cadillac XT4 production, which has been down since February 8, will resume at the Fairfax Assembly in Kansas. GM said production of the Chevrolet Malibu, which is also at Fairfax, will remain down.<\/p>\n<p>The company extended downtimes by one week at Lansing Delta Township and Wentzville, along with an additional week of Chevrolet Blazer production downtime at its Ramos facility.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>GM has extended a shutdown at its Orion Assembly Plant another two weeks due to a battery pack shortage related to the widespread Chevrolet Bolt EV and Bolt EUV safety recall. GM said the extended downtime at the Orion plant will last through September 20. Orion Assembly Plant in Michigan has been shut down since -media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":2401,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/transportation\/","name":"Transportation","slug":"transportation","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/2401"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=2401"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=2401"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=2401"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":576869738,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/chevy-bolt-euv\/","name":"Chevy EUV","slug":"chevy-bolt-euv","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576869738"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576869738"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576869738"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576869738"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576869738"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":197443,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/electric-vehicles\/","name":"electric vehicles","slug":"electric-vehicles","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/197443"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=197443"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=197443"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=197443"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=197443"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":73527,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/gm\/","name":"GM","slug":"gm","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/73527"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=73527"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=73527"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=73527"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=73527"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2198954,"date":"2021-09-09T10:10:48","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T17:10:48","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2198954"},"modified":"2021-09-09T09:27:02","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:27:02","slug":"laser-initiated-fusion-leads-the-way-to-safe-affordable-clean-energy","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/laser-initiated-fusion-leads-the-way-to-safe-affordable-clean-energy\/","title":{"rendered":"Laser-initiated fusion leads the way to safe, affordable clean energy"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Siegfried Glenzer<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\t<a href=\"https:\/\/profiles.stanford.edu\/siegfried-glenzer\">Siegfried Glenzer<\/a>, a recipient of the Ernest Orlando Lawrence Award, is a professor and high-energy-density division director at Stanford\u2019s SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory and a science adviser for nuclear fusion company <a href=\"https:\/\/marvelfusion.com\/\">Marvel Fusion<\/a>.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\">The quest to make fusion power a reality recently took a massive step forward. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.powermag.com\/breakthrough-laser-powered-fusion-experiment-nears-ignition\/\">The National Ignition Facility (NIF) at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory announced the results<\/a> of an experiment with an unprecedented high fusion yield. A single laser shot initiated reactions that released 1.3 megajoules of fusion yield energy with signatures of propagating nuclear burn.<\/p>\n<p>Reaching this milestone indicates just how close fusion actually is to achieving power production. The latest results demonstrate the rapid pace of progress \u2014 especially as lasers are evolving at breathtaking speed.<\/p>\n<p>Indeed, the laser is one of the most impactful technological inventions since the end of World War II. Finding widespread use in an incredibly diverse range of applications \u2014 including machining, precision surgery and consumer electronics \u2014 lasers are an essential part of everyday life. Few know, however, that lasers are also heralding an exciting and entirely new chapter in physics: enabling controlled nuclear fusion with positive energy gain.<\/p>\n<p>After six decades of innovation, lasers are now assisting us in the urgent process of developing clean, dense and efficient fuels, which, in turn, are needed to help solve the world\u2019s energy crisis through large-scale decarbonized energy production. The peak power attainable in a laser pulse has increased every decade by a factor of 1,000.<\/p>\n<p>Physicists recently conducted a fusion experiment that produced 1,500 terawatts of power. For a short period of time, this generated four to five times more energy than what the whole world consumes at a given moment. In other words, we are already able to produce vast amounts of power. Now we also need to produce vast amounts of energy so as to offset the energy expended to drive the igniting lasers.<\/p>\n<p>Beyond lasers, there are also considerable advances on the target side. The recent use of nanostructure targets allows for more efficient absorption of laser energies and ignition of the fuel. This has only been possible for a few years, but here, too, technological innovation is on a steep incline with tremendous advancement from year to year.<\/p>\n<p>In the face of such progress, you may wonder what is still holding us back from making commercial fusion a reality.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>There remain two significant challenges: First, we need to bring the pieces together and create an integrated process that satisfies all the physical and technoeconomic requirements. Second, we require sustainable levels of investment from private and public sources to do so. Generally speaking, the field of fusion is woefully underfunded. This is shocking given the potential of fusion, especially in comparison to other energy technologies.<\/p>\n<p>Investments in clean energy amounted to more than <a href=\"https:\/\/about.bnef.com\/blog\/energy-transition-investment-hit-500-billion-in-2020-for-first-time\/\">$500 billion in 2020<\/a>. The funds that go into fusion research and development are only a fraction of that. There are countless brilliant scientists working in the sector already, as well as eager students wishing to enter the field. And, of course, we have excellent government research labs. Collectively, researchers and students believe in the power and potential of controlled nuclear fusion. We should ensure financial support for their work to make this vision a reality.<\/p>\n<p>What we need now is an expansion of public and private investment that does justice to the opportunity at hand. Such investments may have a longer time horizon, but their eventual impact is without parallel. I believe that net-energy gain is within reach in the next decade; commercialization, based on early prototypes, will follow in very short order.<\/p>\n<p>But such timelines are heavily dependent on funding and the availability of resources. Considerable investment is being allocated to alternative energy sources \u2014 wind, solar, etc. \u2014 but fusion must have a place in the global energy equation. This is especially true as we approach the critical breakthrough moment.<\/p>\n<p>If laser-driven nuclear fusion is perfected and commercialized, it has the potential to become the energy source of choice, displacing the many existing, less ideal energy sources. This is because fusion, if done correctly, offers energy that is in equal parts clean, safe and affordable. I am convinced that fusion power plants will eventually replace most conventional power plants and related large-scale energy infrastructure that are still so dominant today. There will be no need for coal or gas.<\/p>\n<p>The ongoing optimization of the fusion process, which results in higher yields and lower costs, promises energy production at much below the current price point. At the limit, this corresponds to a source of unlimited energy. If you have unlimited energy, then you also have unlimited possibilities. What can you do with it? I foresee reversing climate change by taking out the carbon dioxide we have put into the atmosphere over the last 150 years.<\/p>\n<p>With a future empowered by fusion technology, you would also be able to use energy to desalinate water, creating unlimited water resources that would have an enormous impact in arid and desert regions. All in all, fusion enables better societies, keeping them sustainable and clean rather than dependent on destructive, dirty energy sources and related infrastructures.<\/p>\n<p>Through years of dedicated research at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and the National Ignition Facility, I was privileged to witness and lead the first inertial confinement fusion experiments. I saw the seed of something remarkable being planted and taking root. I have never been more excited than I am now to see the fruits of laser technology harvested for the empowerment and advancement of humankind.<\/p>\n<p>My fellow scientists and students are committed to moving fusion from the realm of tangibility into that of reality, but this will require a level of trust and help. A small investment today will have a big impact toward providing a much needed, more welcome energy alternative in the global arena.<\/p>\n<p>I am betting on the side of optimism and science, and I hope that others will have the courage to do so, too.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Fusion power plants will eventually replace most conventional power plants and related large-scale energy infrastructure that are still so dominant today. There will be no need for coal or livermore national laboratory","slug":"lawrence-livermore-national-laboratory","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576689907"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576689907"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576689907"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576689907"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576689907"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":2092367,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/nuclear-fusion\/","name":"nuclear fusion","slug":"nuclear-fusion","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/2092367"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=2092367"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=2092367"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=2092367"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=2092367"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200170,"date":"2021-09-09T10:00:38","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T17:00:38","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200170"},"modified":"2021-09-09T09:34:58","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:34:58","slug":"supabase-raises-30m-for-its-open-source-insta-backend","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/supabase-raises-30m-for-its-open-source-insta-backend\/","title":{"rendered":"Open source backend-as-a-service startup Supabase raises $30M"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/supabase.io\">Supabase<\/a>, the backend-as-a-service startup, announced this week that it raised a $30 million Series A.<\/p>\n<p>Supabase is often described as an open source alternative to Google&#8217;s Firebase &#8230; which is a pretty good way to put it for those who know what Firebase is. For those who don&#8217;t: Supabase is a collection of tools that helps developers build projects more quickly by automatically handling a whole lot of the behind-the-scenes work and wiring.<\/p>\n<p>Create a project, and Supabase will give you a Postgres database; an API for interacting with said database that automatically evolves (and documents itself!) as your database changes; a user authentication system that plays friendly with the popular login providers (Facebook, Twitter, Google, Apple, etc.); a storage system for handling things like image and video uploads; and a UI for overseeing and managing it all. It takes a bunch of work you&#8217;d need to do to build just about any modern app or service and waves it away with a couple of clicks.<\/p>\n<p>Supabase is free for hobby projects (or when you just want to tinker with it). Once you start needing bigger databases or data backups, the price scales starting at $25 per project per month. Alternatively, you can <a href=\"https:\/\/supabase.io\/docs\/guides\/self-hosting\">deploy it yourself<\/a>, though that&#8217;s a bit tougher and currently means losing the management UI.<\/p>\n<p>This Series A comes pretty quickly following the company&#8217;s last raise \u2014 a $6 million round announced <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/15\/supabase-raises-6m-for-its-open-source-firebase-alternative\/\">in December 2020<\/a>. I&#8217;m told this round was funded predominantly by Coatue, with some of it reserved for a few new key angel investors, including GitHub co-founder Tom Preston-Werner, PagerDuty co-founder Alex Solomon and Docker co-founder Solomon Hykes.<\/p>\n<p>Supabase co-founder Paul Copplestone tells me that the team is now made up of 24 people, distributed all over the world. &#8220;We were born remote,&#8221; he said.<\/p>\n<p>This reasoning is twofold: The company started growing just as the pandemic began to spread, and it&#8217;s largely hiring people who are already working on and contributing to the tools that make Supabase possible. Why make them move around the world when they&#8217;re already doing a good job?<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;We use, I think, six different tools,&#8221; Copplestone said. &#8220;And we employ lead maintainers of several of those tools. We employ open source contributors, anyone who&#8217;s contributing, no matter where they live.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Supabase was part of Y Combinator&#8217;s Summer 2020 class, the accelerator&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/20\/y-combinator-officially-shifts-its-next-accelerator-class-to-fully-remote-format\/\">first cohort to be entirely remote.<\/a> Meanwhile, YC classes are growing increasingly large; the S20 batch, for example, came in at over 200 companies. It can be hard to stand out in a group like that, but Supabase seemed to do it \u2014 I was hearing chatter about them early and often.<\/p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s what it looks like to fire up a Supabase backend:<\/p>\n<p><span class=\"embed-youtube embed breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"><iframe class=\"youtube-player\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/dBOSUER_5T4?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;fs=1&#038;hl=en-US&#038;autohide=2&#038;wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Supabase, the backend-as-a-service startup, announced this week that it raised a $30 million Series A. Supabase is often described as an open source alternative to Google&#8217;s Firebase &#8230; which is a pretty good way to put it for those who know what Firebase is. For those who don&#8217;t: Supabase is a collection of tools that ],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2200214,"date":"2021-09-09T09:42:31","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:42:31","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2200214"},"modified":"2021-09-09T09:42:31","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:42:31","slug":"the-marvel-unlimited-comics-app-just-got-a-major-overhaul","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/the-marvel-unlimited-comics-app-just-got-a-major-overhaul\/","title":{"rendered":"The Marvel Unlimited comics app just got a major overhaul"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/www.twitter.com\/krisholt\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tKris Holt is a contributing writer at <a href=\"https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/\">Engadget<\/a>. \t<\/div>\n\t\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__more-articles\">\n\t\t<span class=\"more-articles-title\">More posts by this contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<ul class=\"more-articles-list\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/02\/locast-suspends-local-tv-streaming-service-in-wake-of-court-ruling\/\">Locast suspends local TV streaming service in wake of court ruling<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/24\/microsoft-will-bring-cloud-gaming-to-xbox-consoles-this-holiday-season\/\">Microsoft will bring cloud gaming to Xbox consoles this holiday season<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t<\/ul>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/tag\/marvel\" data-ylk=\"elm:context_link;itc:0\" data-rapid_p=\"18\" data-v9y=\"1\">Marvel<\/a> is rolling out a brand new version of its <a href=\"https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/tag\/marvel%20unlimited\" data-ylk=\"elm:context_link;itc:0\" data-rapid_p=\"19\" data-v9y=\"1\">Marvel Unlimited<\/a> comics subscription app. Among the updates are exclusive Infinity Comics, which are high-res vertical comics designed for phones and tablets. At the outset, 27 Infinity Comics <a href=\"https:\/\/www.marvel.com\/articles\/comics\/all-new-all-different-marvel-unlimited-app-relaunch-announcement\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-ylk=\"elm:context_link;itc:0\" data-rapid_p=\"20\" data-v9y=\"1\">are available<\/a>, and you should have access to more than 100 by the end of the year. The comics include series such as X-Men Unlimited, Captain America, Black Widow, Deadpool, Shang-Chi and Venom\/Carnage.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed--video\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Experience an\u00a0All-New, All-Different <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/MarvelUnlimited?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@MarvelUnlimited<\/a>. The app with everything you need to read Marvel comics! Here are some updated features to help you dive into the Marvel Universe \u2b07\ufe0f (1\/6) <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/KLuAIhZV1S\">pic.twitter.com\/KLuAIhZV1S<\/a><\/p>\n<p>&mdash; Marvel Entertainment (@Marvel) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/Marvel\/status\/1435956003250581505?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 9, 2021<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>The app, which was redesigned from the ground up with the help of Disney Media &amp; Entertainment Distribution, now offers unlimited downloads for offline reading and a way to share content elsewhere. Marvel&#8217;s promising a streamlined design, more stability, &#8220;best-in-class speed and search tools&#8221; and personalized reading guides based on your preferences. Marvel Insider members will receive rewards for using the app too.<\/p>\n<p>The monthly plan costs $10\/month, while the standard annual option is $69\/year. The $99\/year annual plus subscription includes all the perks of a monthly or regular annual plan, as well as a membership kit, invites to in-person events and a discount at Disney&#8217;s digital store.<\/p>\n<figure><img src=\"https:\/\/o.aolcdn.com\/images\/dims?image_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fs.yimg.com%2Fos%2Fcreatr-uploaded-images%2F2021-09%2F0ba07bd0-1177-11ec-bf7f-8fdda871512c&amp;thumbnail=675%2C&amp;client=49kdj93ncb8s938hkdo&amp;signature=b38f667116d343afdb273c6ae984b27b05a96792\" alt=\"Marvel Unlimited\" data-uuid=\"0a8424d6-af99-3ef9-b1bd-ba9826a135e6\" \/><figcaption><\/figcaption><div class=\"photo-credit\">Marvel<\/div>\n<\/figure>\n<p>Marvel Unlimited hosts more than 29,000 comic issues, with more added each week. However, there&#8217;s at least a three-month gap between titles hitting shelves and Marvel bringing them to the app.<\/p>\n<p>This is a welcome update for an app that was perhaps overdue for a refresh. So, you&#8217;ve been watching Marvel&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/tag\/what%20if\" data-ylk=\"elm:context_link;itc:0\" data-rapid_p=\"24\" data-v9y=\"1\"><em>What If&#8230;?<\/em><\/a><em>\u00a0<\/em>series on Disney+ (or anything else from the Marvel Cinematic Universe) and are curious about checking out the comics as well, it seems as good a time as any to try Marvel Unlimited.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><strong>Editor&#8217;s note:<\/strong> <em>This article originally appeared on <a es\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":449557101,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/apps\/","name":"Apps","slug":"apps","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557101"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557101"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557101"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557101"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557101"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":756,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/comics\/","name":"comics","slug":"comics","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/756"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=756"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=756"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=756"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=756"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":28454,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/marvel\/","name":"marvel","slug":"marvel","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/28454"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=28454"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=28454"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=28454"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=28454"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576900111,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tceng\/","name":"tceng","slug":"tceng","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576900111"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576900111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576900111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576900111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576900111"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2189908,"date":"2021-09-09T09:36:49","date_gmt":"2021-09-09T16:36:49","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2189908"},"modified":"2021-09-09T11:26:21","modified_gmt":"2021-09-09T18:26:21","slug":"plentywaka-founder-onyeka-akumah-on-african-startups-and-global-expansion","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/plentywaka-founder-onyeka-akumah-on-african-startups-and-global-expansion\/","title":{"rendered":"Plentywaka founder Onyeka Akumah on African startups and global expansion"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Plentywaka wants to change<\/span> the way Africans move. It&#8217;s starting with one of the busiest cities on the continent.<\/p>\n<p>The startup, a ride-share and bus-booking platform, is based in Lagos, the Nigerian city where 20 million people and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.afd.fr\/en\/carte-des-projets\/improve-public-transport-lagos-metropolitan-area\">45% of the country&#8217;s skilled workforce<\/a> live. The public transportation system strains under the weight of 14 million commuters who use it daily.<\/p>\n<p>Relying on the public bus can be more than unpredictable \u2014 it also can be dangerous, according to Onyeka Akumah, co-founder and CEO of Plentywaka. The buses are often old, in disrepair and packed beyond safe limits; traffic congestion turns what should be a 30-minute commute into a three-hour journey.<\/p>\n<p>Plentywaka, a combination of English and Nigerian that means \u201cplenty movement,&#8221; was founded in 2019. While it&#8217;s still young, the startup has big plans to ameliorate the public transport infrastructure in Africa and beyond.<\/p>\n<p>Plentywaka has two models. \u201cDaily Waka\u201d offers riders in a city fixed daily routes from bus stop to bus stop. Riders can view the schedule of buses, how many seats are available and reserve seats via the app, which tracks the movements of SUVs, minivans, vans and buses driven by gig workers, also known as \u201cheroes.\u201d When the bus arrives, riders can check in with a QR code, and when they hop off, the app automatically charges the rider via a wallet system.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Travel Waka&#8221; is a newer model that offers interstate travel. It basically serves as a booking engine for other bus companies that offer city-to-city services.<\/p>\n<p>In March this year, Plentywaka was accepted into the Techstars Toronto accelerator program, securing funding as it looks toward global expansion across Africa and into Canada. Just this month, the company also announced expansion plans into Ghana via an acquisition of Star Bus.<\/p>\n<p>Akumah talks us through what the TechStars funding means to Plentywaka, the startup landscape in Africa and tips for African startups looking for investors.<\/p>\n<p><i>The following interview, part of an ongoing series with founders who are building transportation companies, has been edited for length and clarity.<\/i><\/p>\n<p><strong>Before founding Plentywaka, you were the CEO of Farmcrowdy, another startup that connected investors to farmers via a digital platform. What was the impetus for starting a second business? Are you a serial entrepreneur, or do you plan on sticking with this one?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I was the CEO of Farmcrowdy until the end of May this year, but I&#8217;ve handed it over to my other co-founder who is now the CEO, so I&#8217;m fully focused on Plentywaka now. We started Plentywaka in January 2019. I was flying back from Qatar, where I spoke at an event, and landed in Lagos around 8:15 a.m. that day. I had to be at a meeting by 10 a.m., and going through traffic in Lagos is a pain. The state has 20 million people and everybody&#8217;s rushing to work, so I had to abandon my car and take two bikes to make that meeting. When that was done, to make another meeting, I had to take a boat ride across the lagoon. I tweeted about it saying, &#8220;Today, I have flown, I have used two bikes and now I&#8217;m on a boat ride. This is the life of an entrepreneur in Lagos.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>What I wasn&#8217;t prepared for was the shock my colleagues gave me when they said we should experiment with taking the bus. I hadn&#8217;t taken the bus in about 15 years, and I took that trip and had a panic attack. I never knew how frightened I would be getting on a 30-year-old bus with torn-out parts and worn-out chairs. I literally had to hold one of the doors throughout the trip from falling off. That was the day the concept of Plentywaka started.<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Plentywaka, a combination of English and Nigerian that means \u201cplenty movement,&#8221; has big plans to ameliorate the public transport infrastructure in Africa and beyond.\u00a0<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574434,"featured_media":2198986,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"84841069-8042-39cc-ae03-f88a6dc32e78"},"categories":[576869656,17396,2401],"tags":[576854682,96077,66822,576911011,576864686,217609],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[576796356],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Akumah.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3lcamfF","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":true,"premiumCutoffPercent":0.3,"featured":true,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","editorialContentProvider":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[133574434],"hide_featured_image":false,"canonical_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/09\/plentywaka-founder-onyeka-akumah-on-african-startups-and-global-expansion\/","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2189908"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2189908"}],"version-history":[{"count":18,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2189908\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2200184,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2189908\/revisions\/2200184"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574434"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2189908&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574434"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{" With Guidehouse, Sam has worked with numerous clients to help them understand emerging technology trends and shape strategies. Before joining the WarnerMedia family, Forssell served as CEO of Showyou, a video aggregation service that was sold to Vevo in 2015. He was also on the ground floor when Hulu was founded in 2007, helping grow the company grow from ten employees to more than 700, from zero revenue to more than $1 billion, and led its push into original programming. Sahin is one of the world\u2019s foremost experts on messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA) medicines. He has pioneered several breakthroughs enabling the development of mRNA vaccines and other types of immunotherapies. Sahin initiated and oversees \u201cProject Lightspeed,\u201d the historic development of the first mRNA vaccine for COVID-19, moving from lab and clinical testing to conditional approval within an unprecedented 11-month period. He also leads BioNTech\u2019s research and development of neoantigen specific mRNA cancer vaccines which are individually tailored and produced on demand according to the profile of non-synonymous mutations identified by next-generation sequencing in patients\u2019 tumors. Ugur Sahin is co-inventor of more than 500 filed patents applications and patents. Sahin\u2019s academic credentials include serving as a Full Professor (W3) in Translational Oncology &amp; Immunology at Johannes Gutenberg University in Mainz, Germany, where he was the supervisor for more than 50 PhD students.
